summary: This fall, everyone's favorite leche-loving, swashbuckling, fear-defying feline returns. For the first time in more than a decade, DreamWorks Animation presents a new adventure in the Shrek universe as daring outlaw Puss in Boots discovers that his passion for peril and disregard for safety have taken their toll. Puss has burned through eight of his nine lives, though he lost count along the way. Getting those lives back will send Puss in Boots on his grandest quest yet. Academy Award® nominee Antonio Banderas returns as the voice of the notorious PiB as he embarks on an epic journey into the Black Forest to find the mythical Wishing Star and restore his lost lives. But with only one life left, Puss will have to humble himself and ask for help from his former partner and nemesis: the captivating Kitty Soft Paws (Oscar® nominee Salma Hayek). In their quest, Puss and Kitty will be aided--against their better judgment--by a ratty, chatty, relentlessly cheerful mutt, Perro (Harvey Guillén, What We Do in the Shadows). Together, our trio of heroes will have to stay one step ahead of Goldilocks (Oscar® nominee Florence Pugh, Black Widow) and the Three Bears Crime Family, "Big" Jack Horner (Emmy winner John Mulaney, Big Mouth) and terrifying bounty hunter, The Big Bad Wolf (Wagner Moura, Narcos).

I don't usually watch sequels without having seen the first movie, but my family always goes to the movies on Christmas and this was our best option. I was not expecting to like this movie as much as I did, especially because I have grown tired of spin-offs, sequels, and multiverses at the box office. However, this movie delightfully surprised me, and is great on it's own. I loved how like the Shrek franchise, other fairy tale characters are incorporated and modified in unique ways, like Goldilocks and the Three Bears. The animation was entrancing, and I enjoyed how the storyline addressed dark issues, such as death. Overall, this is a great film for children and adults alike, and I am excited to rewatch.

A rarity in Hollywood today - a movie that entertains.  Probably the best film ever made in the Shrek series, or at least of the Puss in Boots series.  Ostensibly a kid's film, this has something for everyone.  My teenagers, wife and I all loved it. It has wild half anime visual style, crazy action scenes, fairy tale craziness (although that shtick has dropped off since the original Shrek).  The humor is not wall to wall, but organic, and almost always lands.  But more importantly, it has more mature themes of coming to grips with mortality and life priorities.  It is an emotional roller coaster and really well done.  Yeah it is a little cartoonish sure, but it IS a kids' film.

This may just be my favorite movie of all time. Not the best movie, The Prince of Egypt and A Beautiful Day in The Neighborhood are the best movies I've seen, but Puss In Boots: The Last Wish is a must-watch. Even as someone who didn't like the first movie, I think this movie soars in every aspect. Puss, Kitty, and Perrito are a great cast of main characters, each of which feel grounded and entertaining at the same time. This movie having 3 villains could have made it feel overstuffed and like it was doing too much, but no one villain takes time from the others and they're all so well written. Jack Horner is a refreshing villain, he is completely irredeemable and evil, something that Disney should do more with its villains if they ever decide to have an actual villain again. Goldilocks and the 3 bears are incredibly sympathetic, well written characters, they're some of my favorites. Wolf was so threatening, generating chills any time he was onscreen. The animation of this movie is so stylized and gorgeous and puts what the first Puss in Boots did to shame. The music is great, "Fearless Hero" is one of my favorite songs from a movie, there's a reason everyone remembers this song after seeing this movie. I could go on and on, but you get the point. Puss In Boots: The Last Wish is an uncontested masterpiece, by far my favorite Dreamworks movie

(SPOILER WARNING) (TLDR AT THE BOTTOM)

This is what animated kids movies should be like. Behind all of the bright colours of the gorgeous animation, making all of the action scenes an absolute spectacle to feast your eyes onto, is a simple plot with an absolutely massive impact. 

The story is light hearted enough so kids can get enjoyment out of it, but it also treats its audience with maturity, not playing safe and having the ‘bravery' to insert extremely deep messages. One of which is the over-arching theme of mortality and how we need to appreciate what we have.

This theme is represented beautifully through its characters. The protagonist puss in boots learns how he has taken his lives for granted. He learns this through the other characters such as Perrito. 

At first glance he seems like the cliché annoying side character for comic relief, but turns out being a warm, friendly and extremely likeable little chap. The fact that he does not have a wish, along with some other character traits, shows us and puss how he is content with the life he has, and only looks forward to his simple dreams, letting the rest develop along the way. His dream is to become a therapy dog, which is an important detail to note further into the film. 

Of course I cannot review this movie without mentioning Death, one of the best animated villains I have seen in a while. He shows puss his hatred towards him for taking his lives for granted, and enjoys inflicting fear into other people. In his introduction scene he is extremely close to taking puss' final life, coming as close to a scar on his forehead, with one drop of blood slowly creeping down to his shocked face. (Another example of this film's maturity) in this scene we see puss experience true fear for the first time in his life, as he is petrified of dying right there, right then. This is the moment he comes to realise how much he has taken for granted, and it was all at the fault of this menacing wolf character.

But it doesn't stop there, he constantly torments puss, showing up throughout random parts of the film, in which every appearance, send massive chills down puss' and my spine, with his truly uncanny whistle. 

One of these appearances leads to what is in my opinion one of the most powerful scenes in the film. Puss begins to run away in a state of absolute to panic before coming to a stop. We see that he is struggling to breathe, and his vision is blurry. Perrito is the only one there, and without any dialogue, Perrito simply rests his head on puss' chest, and in a slow decent into calmness, puss regains his control. Perrito has completed his dream of being a therapy dog. The shear realism of this scene, along with the mature dealing of the situation is what makes this scene, and this film in general truly one of a kind. 

To finalise, we also have many other great characters, most notably, Goldi the three bears, the redeemable villains who learn to appreciate their family, and Big Jack Horner, the pure evil villain who does not appreciate what he has at all, to which he learns to consequences. Overall he is an extremely funny character with a ‘charming evil' to him. All of these characters are balanced out perfectly through the films perfect pacing. Nothing seems to drag on at all.

TLDR:
This movie is an incredible creation. All the characters are amazing in their respected ways, the animation is a true spectacle of passion and creativity, and the plot is simple, but truly impactful with the balance of light hearted humour and the downright mature themes. 

Personal experience:
I have never felt so much towards a film before, the mature themes especially hit hard and really made me look over how I spend my one life. I would honestly not recommend this film to really young audiences, because this film is best experienced when you truly understand the mature tones and messages. I absolutely adored this film, and I hope you did as well.

P.S. this is my first proper review of a film, so sorry if some parts are a bit confusing, and the pacing on this is no where near as good as the films lol. There's so much to say but I don't want this to be too long. But still if you made it this far, even if skipping to the TLDR, thanks for reading, hope i expressed my opinions well enough.

A very funny, colorful and well animated movie. Puss in Boots: The Last Wish goes surprisingly deep into its main character giving a multi-layered personality and a very satisfying character development. The whole cast is particularly efficient to hook you up in their adventure, protagonists and antagonists all shine in their way and give you new favorites in the Shrek Universe. 
Things go fast here since the main goal is to entertain Puss in Boots don't take too much time in event that would usually ask for a little more development. It's notable but not necessarily a bad thing since the characters really help to smooth things with how they command the pacing.
The Last Wish is unexpectedly violent with literal deaths in it, a few drops of bloods, and one of the character is scary. Not a bad point actually, I found it pretty great that they dared to push a little the boundaries of family entertainment.
With a great script and a beautiful final message, Puss in Boots is one of the best animations in the studio and a great movie to watch as a family.

This is a beautiful movie. It worked for and completely earns all of the praise it gets. 

It was visually fantastic. It was emotionally moving. They did a wonderful job telling the story. Even the parts I initially thought would be annoying were great. It was perfectly balanced and had such good messages throughout. 

This movie reminds you to appreciate life and what you have, to live in the moment, to make the most of the time you have, to not let fear control you but that it is ok to be afraid sometimes you just need to work to overcome it. It supports strong family connections, whether that family is biological or not. The antagonists/villains are superb.  It's really funny but still gives the emotional moments time to breath. And this is from a sequel movie to a spinoff about a swashbuckling cat. 

So many movies are the equivalent of junk food and we just keep accepting it and getting more of the same.

Movies like this need to be praised and supported. It's the only way to send a message that we are tired of the constant junk thrown at us.

Enormous thanks to everyone involved with the creation of this gem.

beg for mercy from puss! in boots!

the concept for this film is simple, puss has run out of his nine lives and can only get them back with the means of a wishing star which is in pretty high demand among the bad guys of the shrek cinematic universe. the competition is Goldilocks and the Three Bears and Little Jack Horner who is not so little anymore along with a certain someone who is behind puss for a very specific reason.

the execution of this concept is what makes this film such a treat. the screenplay is straightforward and fast-paced, drags somewhat in the second act but manages itself by the end. the music is perfect for the aesthetic (chef's kiss to be more accurate). the voice acting is muy buena (very good). Antonio Banderas, Salma Hayek, Florence Pugh, Harvey Guillén, John Mulaney, Wagner Moura they're all just fantastic. I was genuinely invested in the characters and not solely on nostalgia. not that this film does a few callbacks but those aren't some cheap fan-services but something that add a little substance to the greater story.

now, the animation and the cinematography. ughhhh, it's so freaking beautiful !!! spiderverse swung in style so puss in boots could land perfecttly on it's feet. there is clearly inspiration for the animation here but instead of some cheap rip-off, it really feels like an artistic choice and comes off as an artist's fairytale come to life here. the movie literally starts with the words "this is a fairytale..." and lives up to it! the cinematography too is something to look out for. this film haz better shots than I can spot in a big budget Hollywood blockbuster these days. DreamWorks atleast never fails in that department and always manages to exceed expectations!

to be honest, I wasn't really expecting anything from this film because the shrek cinematic universe has been near-dead for so long, but this film gives me hope. this film gives me something to put my faith in. you'd think that years of development hell would usually mean bad for a film but not for PUSS!... IN BOOTS!

just go and have a good time with this. and if you haven't yet seen the trailer for the film, don't do it. just go into the film blindly like I did. It will surely give you a few surprises! in my opinion, this is the best film in the Shrek Cinematic Universe since Shrek 2, which isn't saying a lot, but it should since Shrek: Forever After was the only good film after Shrek 2.

P.S.: the new DreamWorks intro is so good. I just love it!

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a truly amazing movie, by FAR the scariest villain I've seen in a while. When he come on screen and the whistling just gave me chills it was perfect, its was like i were being hunted by the one and only death like i can feel the fear he carries. Great project for a kids movie, it add a lot of story to puss like the way he revealed his true colors at the end of the movie and the friendships he have along with the adventures he have, showing that puss is a huge character in the Shrek universe even one of the strongest he last against death in a battle. I really like how they end the movie, SPOILERS they way death gave him a chance at life because he showed who he really is and hes not that overconfident guy who think he can work alone, he shows that he have heart. Death was no longer searching for that same guy anymore he saw his true self i love that, instead of just making it where they made death surrender or die OR show that hes weak. The moral of the story and the text make a lot of sense and was inspiring truly an experience.

The villain in this movie is really scary and the whistling sound that he make gave me chills. I could feel the fear that he carry, like I was being hunted by Death himself. This movie is a great project for kids because it add a lot of story to Puss in Boots' character. We see him reveal his true colors at the end of the movie, and the friendships he have along with the adventures he go on. This show that Puss is a huge character in the Shrek universe and even one of the strongest because he last against Death in a battle.

I really like how the movie end. SPOILERS Death gave Puss a chance at life because he showed who he really is and he's not just an overconfident guy who think he can work alone. He show that he have heart. Death was no longer searching for that same guy anymore because he saw Puss's true self. I love that the movie didn't just make Death surrender or die, or show that he's weak. The moral of the story and the text make a lot of sense and was truly inspiring. The movie is a great reminder that it's important to show our true selves and that we can all change for the better.

In conclusion, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a great movie that you should definitely watch. The story is engaging, the characters are interesting, and the villain is truly scary. The movie add a lot of depth to Puss in Boots' character, showing that he's a strong and complex character in the Shrek universe. The movie's ending is satisfying and inspiring, reminding us of the importance of being true to ourselves. If you're a fan of Shrek or just looking for a great family movie, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is definitely worth a watch.

puss in boots: the last wish is the greatest movie of all time. It saved my firstborn, cured my illnesses, cured my depression, stopped climate change, saved animation as a medium, killed Donald trump, and solved world hunger. In conclusion, the wolf should step on me.

It's great, one of the better movies lately. The characters are great and relatable in various ways, not as flat as expected from animated movie. Love that studio started experimenting with animation styles, and it's not just another standartised 3D jig (looking at you Pixar and your recent years of work that's becoming increasingly muddied stylistically). 
I'm not sure whether Puss in Boots is going to have another story, but I'm pleasantly surprised about where Dreamworks could go after seeing Puss in Boots.

Time to wake up, Disney. Dreamworks has long been eating your lunch, and Puss just finished your dessert. I cannot praise this movie enough. It's a visual feast, hilarious in places and sombre and honest where it counts (and they let the hard-hitting moments linger, none of this wisecracking a joke right away that the MCU does just in case the audience stops laughing for 3 seconds).

The Last Wish is a breath of fresh air. It doesn't harp on at the audience; it doesn't lecture, and it doesn't reiterate the typical "environment good, white men bad" rhetoric that Disney has been repeating since they turned awful. Puss carries a genuinely essential and universal message about making the most of your life, overcoming hardships and bad luck and coming out all the stronger for it with an appreciation for what you have. It may be hard for modern audiences to relate to putting others' needs before your own instant selfish gratification, but it's nice that that's also a theme.

It's fantastic, and I would love to see more studios returning to a more wholesome and honest approach to making movies. Enough woke BS

I watched the movie for the first time a little under two months ago and can I just say, I was in awe. I was in Florida, visiting my grandparents for vacation and it was one of the first things I wanted to do with my grandma while there. I had heard a lot of praise for the movie from my friends (age range 14-20) and since I'm an enjoyer of animation in the first place, I went to go see it. Now, I will say I went into this with little background of how the first movie went - I had watched it once, and that was several years prior. Good thing about The Last Wish, though - you don't need too much background information, so to an extent it can work as a standalone movie if you really want it to be. Going into the actual movie, WOW! The animation was absolutely stunning. They definitely took a lot of inspiration from Into The Spiderverse regarding the animation, mixing the 2D and 3D together. I've seen several reviews saying that made it "hard to watch" or "look cheap", but it was quite the opposite, quite dynamic! It was also very colorful and very detailed, but not too much so - "just right", as Goldilocks would say. Speaking of Goldilocks: regarding the characters, I think they were also very well done. It's easy to root for Puss, he's not one of those protagonists that you get bored and annoyed with, especially with Kitty and Perrito supporting him in his leading role. The villains of the movie were also very well done: Death (the wolf) was quite ominous and accurately embodied Death, "straight up". Goldilocks was a flawed character rather than an actual evil one, and it was nice that her story and wish was resolved at the end in a sweet way, though I will say if I have any critiques at all you could see that from a mile away. Jack Horner, though being the most unapologetically evil character, is also one of the funniest and most memorable of all. Killer design, funny lines, John Mulaney did such a great job voicing him. In fact, all of the voice actors and actresses were flawless - they fit their characters and fit the tones perfectly. 
A lot of reviews against this movie say it's too dark, but I think that's what makes this movie so beautiful. Yes, one of the main topics is mortality, and if that's not something you are ready to talk about with your child - assuming that's who you're going to bring to the movie - then do not bring them. However, if you want them to be able to discuss and see the topic of mortality in a healthy, safe way, this is definitely the movie for you. A lot of media these days struggles in how to discuss death. I think The Last Wish definitely illustrates how ominous and scary the topic of death may be, with its personification of death (the wolf character). At the same time, Puss is able to tackle his fear of death in the end. 
All things considered, this movie absolutely knocked it out of the park. There is so much to enjoy out of this movie, from humor, fun characters, sweet moments, dynamic fight scenes (which do NOT take up the whole movie, by the way!), absolutely GORGEOUS animation, and a killer soundtrack that doesn't get enough credit...and of course, the fact that there is a lot to think about after watching it. 
I highly recommend this movie. Treat yourself and/or your loved ones and go watch it.

Nesta continuação da origem do personagem apresentado em Shrek 2, o Gato de Botas se vê em uma situação desesperadora ao perceber que só lhe resta mais uma vida. Então, determinado a mudar o seu destino, ele parte em busca da Estrela dos Desejos para recuperar as suas vidas perdidas. Nesse contexto, a obra vai surpreender ao apresentar uma série de inovações visuais que mescla elementos em 2D e 3D, proporcionando movimentos dinâmicos e fluidos semelhantes aos vistos em "Homem-Aranha no Aranhaverso". Além disso, a aventura é também muito bem construída e conta com todos os elementos esperados, incluindo ação, emoção e alívio cômico. 

Desse modo, embora a história em si seja um tanto clichê e previsível, todos os personagens são muito bem aproveitados, o que garante uma experiência divertida e envolvente. Além do mais, toda a trama principal e as subtramas dos demais personagens também são bem construídas e exploram temas relevantes como o sentido da vida, traumas, autoconhecimento, diversidade familiar e amizade. Portanto, é interessante observar a presença deles, assim como o antagonista, são fundamentais para enredo ficar completo e equilibrado.

Para tanto, ainda que a trama não apresentar grandes reviravoltas ou surpresas, com uma narrativa previsível e fórmulas conhecidas de outras animações, o filme é capaz de encantar o público com a sua atmosfera única, referências e personagens carismáticos. Portanto, independentemente de a obra ter inspirações em outras animações, ela surpreende com sua execução e inovações pontuais, onde consegue cumprir com excelência o que promete, ao emocionar, arrancar risadas e criar empolgação para futuras continuações.

A sequel to an average spin-off film that struggles to make its own name somehow has a sequel more than a decade later that excels at everything cinema is missing these days. Great storytelling, great villains, excellent character journeys and a kid's film that has more profound and more mature themes that even 12A and 15 films lack. While I admit the Wolf may be slightly too scary for the age range it appeals to in its more vibrant child-like audience, I think it fits into a wider family film that has its laughs for the kids while not being afraid to make an emotional effect on the grown-ups. Kids and grown-ups love this film alike, just what a FAMILY film should do. Family films are now more kid's films that grown-ups watch out of necessity, but Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is hopefully the start of animation going back to being a family occasion and not just a kids-only appeal. Dreamworks could be onto the renaissance of animation, and if the same team is working on Shrek 5, I am definitely on board.

This is the first time where I have seen the audience scores aligned with the critic scores. Normally, I would say critic scores are trying to be cooperate-friendly and be as nice as possible to the movie(the exact opposite of what a critic is ironically), but I have to say, the critic and audience score is very justified. I may or may not update this post, because I have only seen this movie once.

So right now, I am going to be upfront, and write my critiques out of the way so I can talk about the good stuff after.

So, I don't know if it's the effects of my sensory issues and loud movie theater speakers clashing, but it induced a bit of anxiety in me. It could've just be the first few minutes kind of rushing through along with other effects, or it was just loud speakers and my sensitive ears colliding. I really don't know, I would have to rewatch so other time to see. The first few minutes are kind of just a fuzzy memory to me.

I also don't know why they didn't just address the problem between Puss and Soft-paws earlier in the movie. There isn't necessarily anything bad about it, but I feel it would've been better addressed earlier.

That's really my only concerns, not even a problem really.

I think that all the villians are all pretty solid for there being multiple villains. You know what. Scratch that. They aren't just solid villains. They are all really good villains. Plain an simple. 

Jack Horner isn't trying to be relatable at all. He doesn't have some sad back story that tries to get you to sympathize with him. He is just pure evil. He believes only he should be entitled to his power, doesn't give a damn about anyone else, and would do anything to get what he want, even if it means needlessly putting others lives at risk, even those who dedicate there services to him. It is a bit more refreshing to see that we aren't being guilt tripped through a story, and we are being shown that evil isn't made because of bad things. It can just be made in anyone, regardless. Plain and simple. 

He also isn't 2 dimensional either. He might not have a conscious telling him what right and wrong is, but you are shown he has a reason for doing it, even if you don't understand his ideologies or reasonings. It is showcased in ways that you understand what he is doing and why. He knows that once he gets his hands on the power, no one will be able to stop him anyway, and he is confident he can get it.

Ohhh… and death. Death is just amazing to watch on screen. He literally gave me the chills anytime he was on screen, and I love it. That's how you right a villain. When his presence on screen is so intense, that you get chills just seeing him. He is just a badass. Through and through. Nothing else. And I don't mean it metaphorically or rhetorically or poetically or theoretically or any other fancy way. He is a total badass. Straight. Up.

He has so many memorable quotes, I just can't help but reference them as I am writing this review! He is genuinely that fun and memorable as a villain!!! 

He also has a motive that isn't just clear like Jack Horners, but you understand why. And you don't just understand why, his motives are almost justified. You almost root for him at times.

Not to mention Puss in Boots arc where he goes from arrogant ass who doesn't truly value his lives until he realizes he doesn't have any to lose, to one who would like to spend his life wisely and happily, realizing what life is.

Everyone going after the wish has a reason to go after the wish, and then they realize they had what they wished for, and it's just so good. It shows that you could learn to look at what you have and not take it for granted.

I could go on for hours and hours why this movie was such a good movie. But I bet you probably came here for a shorter review just to see if this movie. You didn't come for a whole essay. So I am going to cut it short here and save everyone including myself time. This movie is going to be one of the highest ratings I may ever give to a movie. It's that good. Watch it as soon as possible.

The new sequel to the puss in boots franchise is definitely one one of the best Dreamworks movie that I have seen since Kung Fu Panda 3. The animation was a fresh look over what Dreamworks typically does. The characters were relatable while keeping themselves unique towards the movie. The movie is certainly a must see kind of movie, suitable for all ages.

DreamWorks is clearly saying with this movie that they are now king of the hill in animation films. The animation is incredible and the cast of characters is great. The one thing that sticks out though is the character Death. In my opinion one of the scariest villains in animation history, he defies in any scene giving you goosebumps along with an incredibly intimidating voice given by the talented Wagner Moura. If this is the new standard of what DreamWorks is going to make, I can confidentially say for everyone, we are excited and hope for the best. But please no more Trolls or Boss Baby.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is a thrilling adventure that will have you on the edge of your seat - and it's not just because of the swashbuckling hero himself. DreamWorks has outdone themselves with this latest installment in the franchise, and one of the highlights is the mind-blowing performance by Death Wolf.

This new character, voiced by the talented Idris Elba, is a force to be reckoned with. His menacing presence and cunning tactics make him a worthy adversary for Puss in Boots and his new allies. And when Death Wolf finally unleashes his full power, the results are truly awe-inspiring.

But Death Wolf is just one of many memorable characters in this movie. Puss in Boots, voiced once again by the incomparable Antonio Banderas, is as swashbuckling and charming as ever. And the addition of new allies like Dulcinea (voiced by the delightful Tiffany Haddish) adds depth and heart to the story.

ง

Of course, it wouldn't be a DreamWorks movie without stunning animation and plenty of humor. "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" delivers on both counts, with breathtaking visuals and plenty of laughs to keep audiences of all ages entertained.

In a world where animated movies are a dime a dozen, "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" stands out as a true gem. With its unforgettable characters, thrilling story, and mind- blowing performance by Idris Elba, it's a must-see for anyone who loves great movies.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is an absolute delight from start to finish, bringing back the swashbuckling feline hero we all know and love in a brand new adventure that will leave audiences purring with delight. With stunning animation, hilarious humor, and heartwarming moments that will tug at your heartstrings, DreamWorks has once again proven that they are the masters of family-friendly entertainment.

While Disney may have a storied history of creating classic animated films, "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" shows that DreamWorks is truly a force to be reckoned with. From the intricate character designs to the intricate fight scenes, every aspect of this film has been expertly crafted with care and attention to detail.

If you're looking for a movie that will transport you to a magical world filled with adventure, romance, and plenty of laughs, then look no further than "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish." DreamWorks has truly outdone themselves with this latest installment in the beloved franchise, and it's a must-see for anyone who loves great animation and storytelling.

One of Dreamworks best movies and honestly one of my favorite animated films of all time. The Last Wish is just amazing all around and I'm really happy now that more stylized animation is being used by other studios in a really cool way. This movie was one of the last movies that I thought was going to be really good but I'm very happy that it went above and beyond what I thought it was going to be. The story is pretty cliche and generic yes but it's everything around the story that makes this film so good. The animation is incredibly. The Spider-Verse style works very well for this film and it still stands out from Spider-Verse in its own unique way. The characters and their own respective arcs are great. There really isn't one weak character here. Puss himself gets some excellent development and his journey of grabbing with the concept of death is very emotional and well written. Kitty Softpaws also has a really good arc and chemistry with Puss and Perrito has some really great moments. All of the villains here are great. Goldilocks and the 3 bears all have a good arc and Jack Horner is one of the funniest characters ever included in an animated film and works amazingly well as the irredeemable villain but the real standout here is Death. Death is probably one of if not the best Dreamworks villain. To have Death be personified and built up the way it is in the film is just something else. His interactions with Puss were always amazing. The humor was great as well. Pretty much every joke from Jack landed and all the other jokes were really great as well. Everyone involved with this film felt like they really cared about the characters and the story and that's what makes the film so great. I would highly recommend checking this film out as it's genuinely one of the best films of 2022 and one of the best animated movies ever.

One of Dreamworks best movies and honestly one of my favorite animated films of all time. The Last Wish is just amazing all around and I'm really happy now that more stylized animation is being used by other studios in a really cool way. "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" absolutely took my breath away. This work of art provides everything you could ask for in an animated film. The animation was superb, with a slight action style that added a unique spark to the already beautiful visuals, which had such a variety of themes. Plus, the character design. I'm still getting over how amazing the wolf looked, absolutely horrifying but so fun to watch. The direction was one of the best I've seen in any animated movie, with stunning shots that I'm shocked other films haven't used. The worldbuilding was so compelling, with elements of fantasy and adventure so interesting and thought-provoking, and ideas so brilliant I've truly never seen anything like it. The voice acting was perfect, casting celebrities that are actually good at voice acting, and actors I've never seen before that still were great. The characters were set up so well, with emotional sequences and character building that was heartfelt and realistic, despite the movie being about talking animals and fictional creatures. The comedy was wonderful, with Disney parodies and fairy tale references, plus sequences that were extremely funny. There's practically nothing wrong with this movie- everything was so riveting and fun to watch, always entertaining you while keeping you in suspense. Overall, this is one of the best movies I've ever seen, animated or not. I was invested throughout the entire experience, rooting for characters in their toughest moments, and genuinely tearing up multiple times. This movie is outstanding.

My first cinema experience of 2023, and what a good one it was. I didn't have high expectations - I decided on a whim to see it after two recommendations in separate, unrelated YouTube videos. I didn't even remember this is a sequel. Nevertheless, it was fantastic, and a fantastic standalone film. The animation style is delightful, and similar in many ways to Into The Spiderverse, with an overall painterly, comic book aesthetic and creative use of variable frame rate and colour. The story brilliantly balances real heart with cracking jokes. The characters are all super endearing and energetically acted - suave Puss and his old flame Kitty, effervescent Perrito, relentlessly, comedically cruel Jack Horner, surprisingly familial Goldi and her three bears, and the spectre following Puss everywhere. The story is interesting, taking someone who has grown to think himself untouchable and challenging him to stop thinking about himself for once, and along the way a loner learns to trust again, a dog with the saddest backstory finds a loving family, and an adopted child comes to appreciate her found family. So much else to love - the Shrek cameos, the touching portrayal of a panic attack, the in-universe theme song ("He is your favourite fearless hero"), the touches of anime in fight choreography. I can't wait to see it again.

In my entire life, I have never gone out of my way to rate any movie. Yet watching this…was just a pure pleasure. Never before did I enjoy watching something as I had with Puss in Boots: The Last Wish. I'm always an active critic, yelling in my mind on why the movie is terrible and unrealistic while I'm watching it, yet I didn't do that at all while watching this. 

The story plot line is perfect, it is somewhat bit more fast paced but there is 0 filler or unnecessary moments. Each and every part seems to contribute to a lesson or meaning, and really builds each of the characters that we see in the short amount of time (less than 2 hours). The buildup is solid and the ending is amazing.

The voice acting is flat down some of the best I've ever heard for any animated movie, fantastic and describes each character exactly. I actually never noticed this about any other movies but it really stood out to me from this one. 

Overall the movie is a 10/10, from a solid critics viewpoint.

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a masterpiece. The movie was over 10 years in the making and it shows. Not a single part of it feels rushed, forced, or poorly done. It has gotten stellar reviews on all fronts because the movie is flawless in every regard. It's no wonder that a fantastically executed depiction of one of the most consistently beloved characters in history makes for the greatest movie of all time.
The movie utilizes an animation style inspired by Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, a movie similarly praised by critics, nigh on universally for its fantastic art. Dreamworks used this same system in the production of Puss in Boots, another example of why the decade-long wait after its original announcement contributed to how truly spectacular the movie is. The painting-like style of art created an atmosphere that felt very much like a fairy-tale as opposed to the just-off-reality vibe that CGI movies of the past had, or the totally devoid of realism style of completely hand-drawn movies such as Aladdin or the Lion King. Dreamworks gave us the best that there is in the animated world by refusing to hold back on the art style. The fact that all movies with higher acclaim amongst critics happen to be live action only serves to illustrate why this movie isn't considered better by so called professionals.
	This art-style helps contribute to the simply stunning fight scenes in Puss in Boots: The Last Wish. However, the visuals are not the only thing that makes the swordsmanship in this movie stand out. Unlike other movies using swords, The Last Wish holds a great degree of accuracy to real life swordsmanship. In every single fight, it is clear who is attacking who, who is on offense, who is on defense. Puss can be seen parrying, and then counter attacking with a well executed riposte just like in real fencing. Puss' fight with Death at the end of the movie is the most spectacular fight throughout, with both characters showing off the true height of their ability, utilizing their respective advantages in speed, dexterity, strength, size, cunning, and more and not just pointlessly slapping sticks together between them. What's more, Puss' use of a so-called ‘gatito blade' in his offhand, is highly consistent with the use of parrying daggers, which were quite popular in Italy and Spain for use in rapier fencing. Such historical accuracy is quite rare in TV shows and movies, and for it to be found in a children's movie where that is rarely a concern just goes to show how much effort was put into the movie. Finer details such as these serve to show just how great of flawless masterpiece this movie really is. What's more, every fight in the movie serves a purpose other than just violence for the sake of violence. They help create exposition, advance the plot, and develop characters, whether that be by showing ‘Big' Jack Horner's ruthlessness, the strengthening of Three Bears familial bonds, or galvanizing Puss to be brave and value his lives and the time he has with his friends.
The message of the story is found in the final fight scene. Without having to be explicitly said, the message is still clear, you should cherish every second. The movie also has much to say about how it's ok to be afraid, a lesson many young boys, and all men really, need to hear. It has a flawless and nuanced depiction of a panic attack, something that can't be said for most movies, and shows us that we don't always have as much control as we thought we did, and that's ok. Therein lies the elegance of Puss in Boots: The Last Wish. It is, at its heart, a children's movie, and therefore has the obligation to leave the audience with a clear and positive message. This is no easy task for a movie to accomplish without being heavy handed. Luckily, for the Last Wish, the movie is far from heavy handed, with every message in the story being flawlessly woven into the very essence of the movie, instead of being carelessly stapled on top like so many other movies do. The reward of being appropriate for all audiences and for leaving them all with a positive message is incalculable and one of the many reasons Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is greater than any other movie, despite their higher approval amongst critics.
Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a work of art. It is not only accessible to all audiences, but entertaining to them as well. It surrounds a beloved character that is a known-quantity in his beloved status amongst all, and does him justice in innumerable ways. The movie's attention to detail, and sheer visual beauty set it apart from any other animated movie ever made, while its character development, positive messages, and ability to stay within a PG rating puts it far ahead the dark live action movies that dominate the highest rated spots amongst movie review websites. Dreamworks didn't hold back on this one and, on God, it shows.

The definition of how a franchise matures with its audience.

Just as everyone expected, a sequel to a spin-off to the Shrek franchise that took 11 years to arrive in theatres was the animated movie that took the world by storm. 

The Last Wish really did defy expectations, assuming people had any. The animation style was refreshing for the franchise, the humor was more balanced with the character-driven story, and despite maintaining three different villains the film feels solid rather than clunky. Instead of frequent pop culture references and dodgy jokes that pad for time in the later Shrek films, this Puss in Boots sequel weaves the influences of classic Spaghetti Westerns and swashbuckler films with a family adventure storyline and affirmative, positive themes about appreciating life and those around you. It knows when to be lighthearted and when to be serious, and introduces us to one of the coolest original villains in family animation - a wolf embodiment of death - by not holding back on the menacing aura and instead focusing on it; hopefully the sense of danger will encourage other franchises to stop oversanitizing their films. If I were in the movie's target audience, it would probably be a film I would swear by for the rest of my life (sort of like Shrek 2), but in this case I'll just call it a very good family movie that came out of nowhere.

I hope you're all ready for more Shrek because now it's basically guaranteed to happen. And they will likely be disappointing. (3.5/5)

As a cartoon movie lover, I have watched the movie called Puss in Boots, The Last Wish. I have watched the last Puss in Boots movie in 2011. It seems like it brings back our childhood memories. Due to the technology, the animation is better than the last movie 10 years ago. Puss in Boots is a cat with boots, a brave hero with nine lives. The movie starts with a fighting scene, and he lost the eighth life in the opening battle, and he only has one life. He started to be afraid to die and he wanted to find the wishing star that can give him back his nine lives.

On his journey finding the last wishing star, there are a lot of adventures awaiting and he meet unexpected characters, the one is his lover and the other is a dog, he named him Pero or Perito which means dog in Spanish. His life story shocks to the audience, but he has positive thinking about everything he faced in his life. Apart from Puss in Boots, there are villains who are trying to find the wishing star. There is also a villain is the Big Bad Wolf named Death who is trying to take Puss in Boots's life instead of trying to find the wishing star. If you watch the whole movie, you will know Death is not a villain. The fighting scene between Death and Puss in Boots is epic. Every time Death appears, it makes my bone chill. His style and background music are so artistic.

It is interesting that who got the wishing star, and you will find out because it is unexpected plot twist. Overall, this movie is really good and more than a just fun cartoon movie that a family gather and watch. The animation style and the story line of the movie are great, and I want to say Puss in Boots is coming back with great success.

Puss In Boots: The Last Wish made me sign up to this platform to give a review, that's how good it was. 

The film's animation and art style is amazing, blending stylized 3D visuals with beautiful 2D animation and effects to create a visually appealing movie, on the lines of Spider-Man: Into the Spider-verse.

Then we get the story, a story that deals with the themes of life and death so maturely that you forget this is supposed to be a family-friendly children's movie. And that's because it's a movie for everyone who's protagonist just happens to be your favourite fearless hero, Puss in Boots. 
I haven't seen a film deal with this theme so maturely in so long. The acceptance of one's own mortality being a reason to find things worth fighting for in your one life. 
PIB might be the best interpretation and dealing with said theme i have ever seen. 

And at the heart of it all is a film that doesn't take your time for granted, being around 100 minutes long, short for this current age of cinema, keeps the pace going whilst allowing for those slow moments to make you feel Puss' every thought and feeling on his latest adventure. 

And plenty of fun and entertainment to be had. 

No matter how old you are, you need to go see this movie

DreamWorks definitely took the Crown of 2022 from Disney. I watched 'The Bad Guys' , and thought it was definitely a new step for DreamWorks, as it showed us what animation can give if done correctly. Puss in Boots, The last Wish didn't just do animation correctly, it perfected it. It has a great story which at sometimes can be dark.  Great Character's with well written and each has there own charm. Humour which is funny for children and adults. And best of all, animation with heart, soul and passion put into it. Whether that be it's cinematography, backgrounds, characters, art style or world building, it's those little details like that, that have given animation itself a better name. It's movies likes these that gives me hope, that the animation  industry will wake up more, and realise that people actual want effort for a change, and not the same old way to make money.

I don't usually review movies but feel the urge to, after seeing Puss in Boots The Last Wish! It's been a long time since I came out of the cinema feeling pure joy for a film. I am one of those people who loved Shrek 1 and 2, deciding not to watch the sequels and spin offs after so when I heard about this Puss in boots movie, I wasn't jumping to see it. My partner saw the trailer and was eager for me to watch too. Once I'd seen the trailer I knew there was something special and different happening with DreamWorks this time!

Obviously the visuals were the no.1 thing that drew me to the film. I loved the inspiration they took from Into the Spiderverse. I also see a bit of Arcane and Wes Anderson's Fantastic Mr fox! The fight scenes are epic like Attack on Titan.

The characters are hilarious, and I loved the themes that played throughout. If you've ever experienced anxiety or depression and have started therapy, this movie will probably stir up your emotions (hopefully in a good way). I absolutely recommend everyone see this movie. If DreamWorks keeps this creative team, I'd be excited to see what they'll make next. This is the kind of creation that Disney is falling behind on.

Completing the return to form for DreamWorks Animation that began with Abominable and continued with The Croods 2 and The Bad Guys, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish just might be one of the studio's best films since How to Train Your Dragon 2. With gorgeous Spider-Verse-inspired animation, exhilarating action sequences - though not quite as jaw-dropping as The Sea Beast -, a chilling villain, well-defined characters, some cameos that felt like reuniting with old friends and some really good lessons about coming to terms with your own mortality as well as a beautiful new logo for the studio that's arguably better than the short-lived one from HTTYD 3, Puss in Boots 2 just might be one of the best animated films of 2022. A visually stunning, darkly humourous fantasy adventure that's possibly one of the best installments in the Shrek franchise since Shrek 2.

This was the first animation I watched in 10 years. I was blown away by the artistic style, camera movement and unforgettable cast of characters. Although I'm 22 I was enjoying this move as if it was made not for kids, but for adults.

It exceeded my expectations in terms of plot! It was much more nuanced than the previous movie. All of the characters were once again lovable and with distinct personalities. In some ways, there were many cliche and meme-y moments, but even so, it didn’t bother me at all and simply added to the movie’s charm. Though those moments were cliche, they all served a purpose in sharing a slightly deeper meaning when thought about in a more serious manner. However, the animation style wasn’t better in my opinion. I know many people enjoyed the more cartoony style in this movie, but I think I prefer the older one. This one had frame rates that were slightly too low for me and sometimes the action felt like the theater was experience screen lag. I also appreciated the detail in the first one more. (Slight spoiler) The Last Wish tackled themes of death (and the fear of it) as well as found family, appreciation, pride, and more. I was thoroughly impressed at how the producers executed these themes in a way that is entertaining and for kids while being very honest about them.

This movie is a lot better than it needed to be when studios seem to just pump out uninteresting sequels and spin-offs to grab the cash of poor parents who begrudgingly bring their kids to watch annoying talking animals and bright colors. 

No, this film goes hard. From the fresh animation style to the well written and acted script to the dazzling action scenes, you can really tell the animators and everyone actually put heart and effort into making something pretty amazing. 

It's one of those "wow where did this come from?" moments that makes you forget this isn't Pixar - this is a sequel to a spin-off of a 4 film franchise of which it breathes new life into. 

Along with Sony's Spider-man: Into the Spiderverse and The Mitchells vs the Machines, this Dreamworks film should be a wake-up call to Disney and Pixar who are now at serious risk of falling behind with their tired animation and direction. 

The Oscar nomination for Best Animated Feature is well deserved.

I went to the theaters with high expectations, considering all the good reviews, and believe it or not,they were exceeded IMMENSELY. I'm shocked at how spectacular this film was. It's nearly tied with Shrek 2 as my favorite Shrek related film, it's not quite as good, but it came pretty close. That alone should tell you how good it is. The animation has a "Spider-Verse" like feel,and the action scenes were spectacular. Now lets get to what EVERYONE is talking about, the villain, the literal personification of DEATH. Death is honestly such a scary villian for a kids movie. I was shocked at how intense and suspenseful his scenes were, everytime you heard his whistle, you new stuff was about to go down! I liked Jack Horner as a surprise villian, he's existentense was kinda spoiled by social media, BUT I won't spoil anything here. Goldie locks and the three bears were a fun addition. I'm shocked the film didn't feel overstuffed. Puss in Boots was very good, having to face his mortality and some heavy subject matters. Kitty Softpaws also had a good arc about trust(and the world trust wasn't said a million times like a certain Disney movie) Perito was a funny addition that never got annoying. I love how optimistic he was considering his backstory. This movies story was dark, about Puss being down to his last life and looking for the last wish, and Death hunting him down. This is a MUST SEE, for all ages. 10/10, one of the best DreamWorks and Shrek related films.

Big jack horner not a lot to say casual rich power hungry character just that he is a maniac he doesn't care for his crew or anyone really besides himself and to my surprise he isn't annoying just a grown up child (sad backstory though). Death, there isn't really anything i can say about him that wasn't said before he is the perfect villain he terrifies Puss THE LEGEND who was "never touched by a blade" fear for for his life Puss ran away to Mama luna's cat house some time (story happens) Puss meats death while seeing his previous lives as they mock him for being a coward and not the legendary "PUSS IN BOOTS" and he keeps convincing himself that the wish will make him the legend once again and then Death arrives remembering their previous encounter Puss starts to run (he also saw Death when he kitty softpaws and the bear family jack horner fought for the map) he heard Death's and took off. I went to see this movie this past Sunday, I went into this movie off the hype I was hearing about from other people, so my expectations were high for the movie which can often only end in disappointment when a movie doesn't live up the the idea of it within your own mind. 

I'm glad to say the movie not only met my expectations but sailed way above them.

The voice acting, sound effects, animation, story and camera angles in every scene were phenomenal; from the most gripping fight scenes to the most heart-warming scenes. To compare I recently also went to see the sequel to Avatar as well and if I was asked to make a choice between the two it would but Puss in Boots without hesitation. 

The characters and story had development and character arcs that I didn't expect to have in a Puss in Boots movie however that only made the movie the more refreshing and gripping. You've got heroes and villains that are incredibly relatable as well as the comically villainous villains which all culminates an incredible finale for the characters and viewer. 

If you've the choice between this and any other movie out right now; pick Puss in Boots.

Puss in boots the last wish is the perfect animated film.
You might think I'm exaggerating because its an animated dreamworks  film about a talking cat in shoes from the shrek universe going on a typical adventure but that's because you aren't looking deeply enough into the film about a talking cat form the shrek universe. Puss in boots is at its core a story about the idea of "laughing in the face of death" and coming to terms with our undeniable mortality and a story of living your one (or nine) lives the best you can. It's a story that juggles anxiety and panic attacks paired with the feeling that death is looming around you constantly, waiting to strike. And it's a film about what fear does to you and what it does to your relationship and your life

Puss and boots starts with Puss going on a normal adventure,  throwing a party and then killing a giant. But then he dies. Which he seems completely unfazed by until he realizes he's on his last life. And is prescribed "retirement." 

I've never been a fan of the dreamworks art style. Its just never stood out to me. But with Puss In Boots  The Last Wish  I genuinely enjoyed the way they animated it. Their use of the more 2D art style in a mostly 3D animated film was gorgeous and definitely did more than offer a nod to Spider-Man into the spiderverse. It genuinely excites me that one of my favorite animated films, Spider-Man into the spider verse, could be having such an effect on animation and the industry. The animation in Spider-Man into the spiderverse genuinely made me so happy and I thought the scenes were absolutely gorgeous. I've been animating for multiple years now and I've won competitions for my animation and I LOVE animation analysis and both of these movies really stand out to me.

Not only is this movie gorgeous but it's also smart. This movie,as I said, tackles bigger topics and enthralled you with its gorgeous animation but it also appeals to the right audiences. Because of course it's a kids film so kids are going to watch it but who's taking them to the movies? Adults. How do you appeal to adults?" That's a question the animation industry has been looking at for years. They've tried things such as, more adult jokes, which the shrek universe is famous for. But in the end they just feel like cheap laughs. I took my dad and my sister to see Puss In Boots the first time I watched it and my dad genuinely laughed at parts. He found lots of teh humor amusing such as, The Jiminy cricket sketch and the Goldilocks dynamic. This movie appeals to lots of people and does it well. ANd they have the numbers to prove it.

Bravo of taking on the topic of 'death' in a very kid friendly way. And while the 'wish upon a star' is not new or a fresh take, been done and is more ownable by other franchises, the movie managed a fresh take on the journey through the Black Forest to reach it ...so giving credit where credit is due.

This movie is a masterpiece. Everything about it is perfect - the story, the characters, the animation, the sound design, even the pacing. It's an absolute pleasure to watch and I recommend it to everyone.
The story is great, despite being an animated movie deeply connected to ones made previously for children, it doesn't sway from tackling more deep and challenging problems. The main characters go through a lot in this movie and it is reflected by their behaviour.
The sound design is immaculate, certain sound cues being played at perfect times to signal danger, fear, or comfort. It is perfect to the point of the whistling one character does becoming very iconic, and every time it appears you know they are near.
The animation is top notch, workers at DreamWorks clearly putting in a lot of effort to create the best in a long time. Characters move through the environment clearly, interacting with it as they go, making us feel like they really are there instead of just being pasted in later. The animation is fluid, so when an enemy moves with less frames per second you can tell they are dangerous and clunky, and when later the same animation style is done to the main character while escaping you know they are the ones in danger. The animators doing little tricks like the one previously mentioned shows just how skilled they are in the art.
The characters are all memorable, each one's personality being very defined and different from the other's. This leads to some conflicts but also is a nice way for them to interact without it feeling forced. The new additions to the cast - the little dog, the main villain and others don't feel shoe horned in, instead feeling simply like extensions of the world we just haven't seen before.
This movie was masterfully done in all aspects, and I cannot recommend it enough to everyone. You should most definitely watch it or you'll miss out on one of the most amazing movies I've seen in a while.

I am a 23 year old man and this 'children's' animated movie has become my favourite film of all time. It is perfect in every aspect, story, characters, pace, dialogue, animation, sound track, all of them 10/10. I can genuinely think of no faults to this film and it is one that can be thoroughly enjoyed by all ages, perfectly balancing light hearted comedy with some deeper themes and important life questions and messages . I will be going back to see it on the cinema screen several times before it leaves theatres and I will be bringing as many family and friends as I can because it is just that amazing!

This movie was absolutely incredible! It has a very good message about the value of life and some of the best villains/antagonists I have seen. The significant characters had a captivating screen presence and were all so much fun. In addition to that, It portrays anxiety in a realistic way when it shows Puss having a panic attack. The visuals were a stunning mix of 3D animation, watercolor, and that Spiderverse-ey style.

As far as story goes, it serves its purpose of humbling Puss and develops his character in a believable way while still keeping him as the same lovable feline.

I admit, I initially thought Perrito would have been the stereotypical annoying Kevin Hart side character, but I couldn't have been more wrong. He was surprisingly lovable and endearing. He even helped Puss through a panic attack in the same way REAL therapy dogs do. 

Jack Horner was absolutely hilarious, Goldilocks and the three bears were surprisingly wholesome, and Death filled me with pants-shitting fear every time I heard his whistle.

Puss in Boots: the Last Wish is altogether an incredible movie, 100% a must watch.

The Hero's Journey is an absolute timeless classic. Puss in Boots manages to frame that perfectly into it's own theme while developing side characters just as well.

На мой взгляд, это лучший анимационный фильм снятый за последнее время, в нем незамысловатый сюжет (движение из пункта а в пункт б), простой злодей который злой сам по себе, однако этому мультфильму не нужны эти сюжетные осложнения, ведь в это не было целью создателей, этот мультфильм раскрывает нам кота в сапогах не как неустрашимого безупречного героя, а как простое самовлюблённое и эгоистичное существо, которое изо всех сил пытается оттянуть собственную кончину и избежать смерти, однако на этом пути он изменяется и понимает, что конца не избежать и необходимо жить здесь и сейчас и дорожить тем что имеешь. По итогу могу сказать, что если этот мультипликационный фильм нельзя назвать не побоюсь этого слова шедевром, то мало какое произведение может претендовать на это звание.

This movie is the best movie I've ever seen, I am disappointed with it only having 95 on the tomatometer, it deserves more, but 95% is still high.
Anyways, let's get in topic.
In this review, we will have 7 categories to cover and rate.
Characters: The characters are a sweet and pure 10/10, their backstories are very creative with goldilocks, perrito and jack horner, and the characters don't make you feel like they are just added in because the studio can, it makes you feel that every characters have their main purpose of being in the show, every character is just a puzzle piece in this movie.
Casting: The cast for the movie is gold, 9/10! John Mulaney fits the role for jack horner, and Death sounds so good! every character feels like if the animation speaks without any person voicing it! mouse syncing is very good too!
Villains: 11/10, no explanation here, Wait no, 11+/10 it's not gold IT'S DIAMOND!
Animation: Animation is SUPER GOOD! like how they use a similar style with one of the best movies out there, Spiderman into the spiderverse! but instead of making the visuality looks like a comic book, they made the visuality looks like a fairy tale book, it looks so bright and actually give that art made out of paint/ fairy tale book vibe!
Plot: 12+/10, the plot is what brings together this magnificent movie, so no explanation same for the villain!
Action: 100/10 this is like an anime type of combat/fighting, fast paced, effects that is more likely to make you watch every single part of the scene and sounds in those scene are so satisfying!
Soundtrack: 8/10 fearless hero is a banger, my favorite out of the bunch is horner heist, no context.

Another family friendly feline flick. A story of family, friends, and the ideal value one should place on what is truly important in their lives. My 10 year old loved being familiar with all the characters and their individual stories. Some tear jerker moments, a lot of good chuckle moments too. The animation reminded me of the movies before but they seemed to have implemented a sort of comic book-esque style of animation as well. If you're familiar with the animated Spider-Man, that's where it felt like it was pulled from.

Wow. Okay, a kids movie about a cat with boots was not one I expected to hit every single mark I have in order for a movie to be considered "great." 

And yet, here I am.

Everything about this movie is really phenomenal. I wasn't going to go see it, but heard good things and thought, "well, I haven't been to the theaters in a while. Why not?" So glad I did. I will be going again. The storytelling is literally PERFECT (or puurfect? ...sorry). It doesn't treat the audience as stupid, everything just flows so perfectly, and there's no lecture telling us what the moral of the story is--instead, the movie trusts in its own ability to tell a story. The villain/s are fun and interesting. The humor actually lands. I actually cried. Who knew an animated movie about a cat would bring me to tears?

This movie hits home on so many levels, addressing so many raw, human fears that are incredibly relatable. It has a good moral, and good sub-morals. And it's fun. It's so much fun to watch. Highly recommend. I'll definitely be buying this on DVD when it comes out.

Puss In Boots: The Last Wish has plenty of heart, colour and charisma that's brought to life not only from it's visuals (that are quite simply fantastic) but from a passionate voice cast that oozes energy. Vapid and superbly edited action scenes that carefully utilise it's Spider-Verse style swagger at the right moments. Humour that hits more than it misses. Satisfying story arcs and Emotional beats. AND all of this is seasoned with a delightfully mature approach towards it's themes, proving yet again that the best ‘kids' films are the one's that – much like it's terrifically scary villain - aren't afraid to get a little dark.

Watching the beginning song and dance sequence that introduces the newly animated look of puss, I was dismayed at the cheap looking slapstick action lacking any of the charm that oozed from all the characters in the original that had incredibly detailed expressions.  It set the tone for the whole rest of the movie.  All the clever humour and emotion that appealed just as much to the adult audience was gone and replaced by Hanna-Barbera type cartoony action. this movie was a wonderfully crafted masterpiece. dream works out did themselves by finally making the puss and boots movie many early 2000s viewers of Shrek 2 have been wanting to see since the introduction of puss. 
the movies story was incredibly thought out and had so much genuine character something the first film lacked. speaking of characters every single character was amazing going back to the twisted fairy tales we have seen all the way back with the first Shrek. each character was well thought out from Goldie and the 3 bears to jack hawner each one was fine crafted. i must personally say though that there was a definite outlier. Death. every single time he was on the screen he stole the show. from the design to backstory and his signature eyrie whistle the designers knew exactly what they were doing by making Death as bad ass as he is. 

the story and characters all though excellent would not have been as marvelous if the animators stuck to the original Shrek style. instead, they overhauled it and went with a much more spider verse style which perfectly complemented the story and action to a tee. i love that the company understood what made the last puss in boots movie so flawed and set out to make perhaps one of what must be the pinacol of animated movies up there with the likes of how to train your dragon and toystory. everyone i went to watch this with was talking about the animation and characters for hours after our first watch and i personally can not wait to watch it again as well as draw some fan art for this movie 

Dreamworks pride yourself on a movie made perfectly and please keep up the top work. additionally if i could give you a higher score i dam well would.

With 2022 bringing many mediocre movies to the table, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish left 2022 with a bang!

From being just an off shoot from the Shrek Franchise, this movie really lives up to the legendary name of Puss in Boots. The 2011 film being just a meh movie of Puss in Boots really didn't feel remarkable in any way, but The Last Wish? This is what makes movies so great to watch!

 Such a simple plot to follow accompanied with such rich and dynamic characters and relationships really keeps you to wanting to see more of these characters interacting and talking. 

Not a single character felt underutilized. Even the characters that didn't have much screen time had their role fulfilled. The story had such maturity with several difficult topics to tackle for a PG film. They absolutely handled them correctly and almost perfectly. Humour is definitely a strength of this movie, with a broad range of jokes from such different characters.

Illumination needs to take notes; Dreamworks has laid out the blueprint on how to make a good sequel. This movie was fantastic, and it started with the animation. I love this new visual direction that the Spider-Verse is pushing everyone into, and Puss in Boots: The Last Wish capitalized. The action sequences were so quick and comic-like, and the colors popped. Beyond the look, the story was quite good as well. Dreamworks picked a good handful of messages to deliver and they did it well. I especially liked the arc with Goldi and the Bears, but the very real and very persistent personification of Death was also…fun? Maybe not the word, but I was very interested. There was a great blend of heart and humor and the voice cast was outstanding, especially Florence Pugh and John Mulaney. This is certainly the best kids' movie I've seen in a while, and I hope the Minions take full offense.

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish had a lot to live up to as most of my critic and casual friends have been praising the film, and for the most part the film delivers.

From the opening frames, the unique art style fills the screen and is incredibly captivating. There is some excellent combination of 3D animation with 2D styles that I have not seen before. The combat frame rate shift was also a nice touch that worked better than I was expecting. Action was top notch with some incredible set pieces and superb choreography.

The Last Wish deals with some pretty heavy themes for an animated children's movie. Death is something that all humans will have to face which was handled in such a nuanced and mature way here. From panic attacks to haunting imagery, death looms large throughout the entire film and serves as a menacing villain. The journey our heroes take to confront this fear is very heartwarming and will resonant with most audience members.

With most DreamWorks pictures, the comedy is targeted at both children and adults. I did find myself laughing out loud at plenty of jokes, but just as many landed flat for me. This would be more of an issue, but this is an incredibly balanced film with great action and dramatic moments that leave little room for a few flat jokes to make a large impact on my experience.

I genuinely believe that this movie has restored the Shrek universe and can propel the future projects upward. Hype has officially been restored for Shrek 5!

The only explanation I have for all the positive reviews this movie is getting is that most of them come from adults who watched it with teens or without children. We went to the cinema with a group of 6-10 year old children (trusting the "6 and above" rating this movie got in Germany) and it was an awful experience for them.

Copious amounts of violence (some cartoonish and played for laughs, some way too intense for kids), references to and portrayals of gambling & alcohol, a lot of swearing & rude language (sometimes censored, sometimes not), references to animal abuse (partially played for laughs) and an anthropomorphic wolf character who symbolizes death and who's significantly too terrifying for young children. Multiple kids in the cinema started crying, had to be escorted out of the hall, or had to close their eyes for large stretches of the movie. At one point a character calls another character a "p*ssy" - which is a somewhat lame cat pun in the original English, but in German that's lost in translation and ends up being straight up vulgarity that has no place in a movie rated 6+. Beyond those crassly child-unfriendly elements, the plot of the movie and the underlying themes (living the life you got, facing death & fears) were neither interesting to nor understandable for our kids. Another issue was the fake Spanish accent of the main character. Since we saw the movie in German I can't judge the original voicework, but in the German version the main character was sometimes very difficult to understand even for the adults.

This movie illustrates a larger problem: age ratings have become practically meaningless, and we essentially need to pre-screen every single movie we're considering to show to our kids to make sure it's actually age-appropriate and won't cause pedagogic issues. In this case, trusting the German film rating board (the FSK), reading reviews and watching the trailer beforehand was evidently not enough, and we regret taking our kids to this movie. Thank you, FSK, for deciding that a movie that makes our kids leave with the mental image of someone drowning a puppy in a river is appropriate for ages 6 and above... 🙄

Those issues aside, from an adult perspective this movie was thoroughly "meh". The comic-book animation style was neat for the first few minutes, but became jarring later on since it was applied very inconsistently. The plot was somewhat bland and the characters didn't really stand out (with the possible exception of the dog). The side-plot of the bear girl and her adopted family felt tacked on, and the ending felt somewhat satisfying but very telegraphed. Most of the jokes weren't offensively bad but didn't really land either, and most of the references just served to remind us of older, much better movies that we could have been watching instead. The quality of the voicework (keep in mind I'm talking about the German version specifically!) ranged from okay-ish to aggressively poor.

Definitely not a movie we're going to see again, and definitely not a movie we would have shown our kids had we known what we were getting into beforehand.

I will say as someone who has always been interested in the animation industry for quite some time now, this has to be one of the most inspiring pieces of media to come out in recent years. With all honesty, I haven't been so lifted from my seat and excited about a film such as this since "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse", which I must thank for the seismic level shake it had on other studios for taking animation to the new level of storytelling which I believe this film provided. The Soundtrack as well is outstanding! Every single song on the album is a worthy hit which deserves to be replayed again and again, don't believe me, go check it out on Spotify or YouTube! Anyway, as much as the film was a flavorful and visual expressive ball of energy, it knew the perfect moments to slow down and take in impactful moments, and allow their audience to take it all in. Which leads me to discuss the topic of the film, Mortality, and by the stars! They encapsulated it perfectly. I was moved, for I believe it is something all ages and walks of life can understand, the inevitable and looming presence which death holds within all of us. The anxiety which we hold until we too are at that pass which we face the inevitable. Nonetheless, we continue and decide to make the most of the single life we are given, to fight for the life we want with those we love and care for. I have not seen a film tackle such a hard and difficult subject in quite some time, and successfully I might add. In conclusion, this is an outstanding and captivating film which deserves to be talked about for years to come.

Is the prettiest and best animated western children's movie in existence? Yes.

Is it more than that? Not really. The opening fight sequence is fantastic, and any time the animation team executed on an action scene, holy crap they were hitting home runs.

But at the end of the day, beyond a few scenes of genuine wholesomeness and tenderness, it's still just a western animated children's film. If that's all you ever watch, you're going to be very pleased. If you enjoy broader media, this is fairly formulaic.

Goldi and the Bears carry the film.

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is truly an amazing movie that people need to watch. This movie is easily one of the best children's movies out there and a lot more people need to see it. This movie is about characters trying to get the wish they want and they are doing anything to get it but while Puss is trying to get his wish, we see how scared he is of the new villain Death and how much fear he gets. We can see how Puss is trying to get his 9 lives back while meeting his old wife and making a new friend to get the wish. At the end of this movie, we get to see how Puss matures and leaves the last wish while fighting Death to let go of the fear of dying. This movie is truly special and shows you not to be scared of something and to fight back.

I'm amazed how popular this film is. I presume much of it has to do with how much we all love Antonio Banderas's Puss. 

The first film was brilliant -- it truly had everything for just about every demographic and I'm not sure I stopped laughing from beginning to end. I even enjoyed watching several episodes of the TV series that followed, with my daughter, who is now 8-years old.

This sequel was disappointing on so many levels, not the least of which was: editing) it was too long; 2) story line -- a bit thin, even for an animated feature; 3) and this is the most important, the writers/directors didn't seem to understand the kind of film they were making. While I understand the nature of the Puss in Boots created for the first film (which I love), as being a heroic and hopelessly non-self-reflective figure (which makes him so wonderfully funny), the sequel seemed to think it was produced by Marvel Studios, filled as it was with over-produced action sequences that were simply boring and repetitive (hence the need to cut 10 minutes). 

This will make a great case study in film school on how you take a sure thing and screw it up.
