This movie was way better than I thought it would be, especially for a spin off sequel of a Shrek character. I really like how this movie handled the theme of grasping onto your mortality and realizing what's actually important in life and that it's more than just "living up to your own legend". It really made Puss look a look at himself and forced him to realize all that he took for granted in favor of his pride. 

The animation was great! I love it when animation strays away from hyperrealism and gets experimental like this. I wish more movies to be inspired by Spiderman: Into the Spider-verse and I want it to be a trend. Humans are very artistic creative!! We should express that more!

My only gripe is that while I actually enjoyed every character in this movie, I kind of wish the Bear family had less screentime or not exist at all in favor of focusing more on fleshing out Puss, Kitty, or Perrito. I was way more invested in those three than the B plot, but honestly the Bear family was enjoyable enough anyway. 

All in all, I loved the movie and while I feel some of its potential was untapped I think this is a great step forward!

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish was a phenomenal movie. The action, animation, and art style are all top-tier. The amount of work the studio put into the animation scenes must have been incredible, because I can't stress enough how fluid the animation was. I did some background research, and the animation team that worked on this movie also worked on Spiderman: Into the Spider-Verse, which makes sense. You definitely see it in their quality of work. The story itself was unexpectedly deep. I must say that, for a children's film, the themes and symbolism are all quite complex and powerful. If you are an adult watching with children, I strongly advise you to pay attention. The morals of the stories at the end are all very heartwarming. Goldilocks, the Three Bears, and Puss in Boots are among my favorites. Overall, a fantastic film.

After wallowing in mediocrity for over a decade making low effort movies, DreamWorks reasserts itself as a leader of animation just like they did in 2001 when they popularized and made the genre of 3d animation into the powerhouse it is today.

I think they learned their lesson after being outshined by other studios for so long and decided to go back to the drawing board. It's clear Sony's Into The Spiderverse was a big inspiration for the movement, camerawork and stylization. They do their best to make the fights as dynamic as possible with long shots with a camera as well animated as the characters as they swing and jump around the scene with impressive fluidity. 

The movie aims for a step above the more lowbrow elements of the Shrek franchise while retaining all of its defining charm and creativity, making it one of the most impressive accomplishments of the DreamWorks team alongside Shrek 2 (another incredible sequel).

Beautiful animation, vibrant colors that are appealing to the eyes, and good plot, pacing, and comedic timing. Casting was also very good too, especially John Mulaney's performance. Enjoyable for all ages!!

This sequel is far more appealing than its predecessor in every way. From the beginning of the movie, captivating animations combined with adventurous music attract watchers' attention. Before watching the sequel, I had low hopes for this movie, but my opinions were immediately swayed at its very start. This film grabbed my attention in a way much different than the first Puss in Boots did.

In The Last Wish Puss realizes that he's used up his 9 lives- except 1. A Grim Reaper haunts him everywhere he goes, reminding him of his possible death. Puss learns of a wish he can make on a star, which he decides he will utilize to receive more lives. He meets a chihuahua and an old friend on his way to find the star. The movie covers his adventure to find the star and includes heartfelt scenes between multiple characters. 


Overall, the animations and scenery in the movie are enough to draw watchers' attention. The plotline of the movie is very interesting for viewers of all ages.

I didn't see the original Puss In Boots from 2011, and I'm one of the seemingly very few people who's never been a fan of the Shrek franchise. Imagine my surprise then, when I sat down to watched the feisty feline's latest cinematic venture, The Last Wish, and got a massive kick out of it. I don't have anything against the character, he just happens to be a secondary player in a film series I never liked, so he was never on my radar. But his newest film is, from what I've heard, superior to the original, and certainly more well regarded than the later Shrek flicks. Its not only got a lot of great comedy, but it manages to have its share of serious moments, and treats them with respect. When the characters are musing on the importance of family, loyalty and the perils of mortality, the film isn't constantly throwing in one liners of making obnoxious gags that take you out of the moment. As such, the characters feel real and, for lack of a better word, human. The quest is fun engaging because you know what each individual wants and why they want it, the animation, borrowing heavily from Into The Spider-Verse, uses imperfections and roughness to make things look more like classic fairy tales, and when the comedy hits, usually unexpectedly, it gets big, well-earned laughs. Unlike Spider-Verse, it's not a game changer, but the effort that's been put into its appearance, it's story and its characters, makes it more than worth your time.

Puss in Boots, the charming and charismatic feline from the "Shrek" franchise, is undoubtedly one of the best movie characters of all time. Here are 10 reasons why: 1. Puss in Boots is a classic fairytale character with a modern twist. He is a swashbuckling, sword-wielding hero, but also has a playful, mischievous side.
2. He is a master of disguise and deception, able to fool even the most formidable foes with his cunning and charm.
3. Puss in Boots has a strong sense of loyalty and honor, always standing by his friends and fighting for what is right.
4. He is a skilled warrior, able to defeat enemies with ease using his sword and acrobatic abilities. 5. Puss in Boots is also a romantic figure, always on the lookout for true love and willing to go to great lengths to protect it.
6.He is a role model for children, showing them the importance of courage, integrity, and perseverance.
7.Puss in Boots is voiced by Antonio Banderas, whose performance brings a unique energy and charisma to the character.
8. His soft and fluffy appearance, combined with the rough and tough attitude, makes him unique and lovable.
9. Puss in Boots is a character that resonates with audiences of all ages, making him a timeless classic.
10. He is an iconic character that has become a cultural phenomenon, with merchandise, spin-offs and a solo movie.
Overall, Puss in Boots is an unforgettable and memorable character, his charming personality, heroic actions, and his unique abilities make him one of the best movie characters of all time. He is a true embodiment of what a true hero is and he will always be loved by audiences worldwide.

Film magnifique que ce soit dans l'animation ou les messages transmis. Le personnage principale casse son image de héro parfait et sans peur pour devenir plus humain (ironique pour un chat) mais il n'est pas le seul à être intéressant. Perro amène avec lui beaucoup d'humour malgré un passé très noir mais compense avec un optimiste à toute épreuve. Boucle d'or et la famille d'ours m'ont aussi touchés au point où j'aimerais bien voir leurs prochaines aventures. Les antagonistes, eux, sont très différents avec Jack Horner qui est le méchant pur et sans once de gentillesse ce qui contraste bien avec le "méchant" que tout le monde à retenu : La mort. Pour le coup, je ne le considère pas comme méchant car il est là pour faire son boulot et le fait qu'il laisse le chat potté à la fin témoigne de l'évolution du personnage principale. Un antagoniste lourd de sens qui rien à son sifflement ferra donner des frissons aux spectateurs tel la respiration de Dark Vador.

i went into this expecting a light-hearted shrek-universe kind of comedy packed movie. as the first puss in boots, nothing too serious, nothing too brilliant, but funny enough that it would keep be busy for an hour and a half.

i was gravely mistaken, and i greatly underestimated this film.

it was packed full of comedy, but it was also very serious in the crucial moments that needed it. not only that, but it was absolutely brilliant. everything from the animation and effects to the voice talents, it was quite literally brilliant. on my first watch, i was in a nearly empty movie theatre, save for about 10 other people. and i cried my heart out at 2 very distinct scenes, and then a third time when the lights in the theatre came back on, as i realized that this moment, me enjoying this incredible cinematic experience, was over. so what did i do ? i went back to the theatre two days later and rewatched it. and then i watched it a third time. i watched this movie in theatres three times within the same week. and yes, i cried those other times i watched it too.

i could go on and on about how great this movie is, but i dont want to spoil anything, and id rather people go watch it themselves.

please go see it. you will not be disappointed.

I wish I was lying when I say this is the best movie I've seen in a WHILE. I went with a friend as a joke just hoping for something half-decent and was shocked at how much I genuinely enjoyed it. The animation was beyond incredible, specifically during fight sequences, but also just in general. Dreamworks has been hitting it out of the park recently as far as animation goes and this may be their best yet. I expected a cute but corny kids movie and got a commentary on embracing life in all of its brevity. The protagonist's story line was devastating, the villain was terrifying, I laughed out loud and cried multiple times, and walked out of the theater wanting to be a better person. The visuals, the voice acting, the story line- there's nothing wrong with this movie. I have never called a movie perfect before, but that is exactly what Puss in Boots: the Last Wish is.

THIS MOVIE IS THE BOMB!! 

For one, this movie handles serious topics such as anxiety and death very maturely and isn't all in your face about. Best of all, it doesn't degrade or ruin the character in any way. It gives actual character development and makes it so relatable to watch!

Two, this movie has great characters with depth and deeper layers that help make them more likable and better to see. For example, Goldilocks wanted a family of her own blood but throughout the film, she realizes that she didn't need a family like that and finally learned a family is connected by love rather than DNA. Now THAT is depth right there!

Three, the animation is amazing. It is so refreshing to see Dreamworks step out of their comfort zone in animation and try a new style to a point where everything is more vivid and colorful instead of the typical semi-realism we see in Dreamworks films.

Four, IT HAS A GREAT VILLAIN! I know it may sound like a not-so-big deal at first but once you really think about, the villain is always the hardest character to write and organize because everyone has a different idea of a villain and how they can give audiences a fearful presence. Well, Death was a perfect example of a villain because he was bigger and felt thrill in being the bigger person and scaring Puss. Plus, his Whistle of Death is terrifying and can absolutely be frightening to both Puss and the audience. The writers also were so good in giving Death a vibe that communicated clearly to the audience that in a way, he was there and he knew that Puss was foolishly wasting his lives. 

Fifth, it gives a fresh breath of air to character tropes that are rarely used today and actually makes them well-written! Jack Horner is a very good example of that because he is a psychopath who is beyond redeeming and chooses to be evil and blunt with his motives instead of relying on a tragic backstory to back him up. That, my friend, is how you make a good unapologetically evil villain. No relatable, no tragedy, just a fun but psychotic villain. 

And finally, the voice acting. I love how Dreamworks actually doesn't rely on famous people to boost their film but rather on them boosting it on honest work and good writing like any decent movie should do. The voice actors/actresses all did an AMAZING JOB in delivering the right presence into each character only seen through concept work, and that my friends, is difficult to achieve so a VERY BIG ROUND OF APPLAUSE TO THEM!!!

So overall, this film is amazing, genius and very original and ground-breaking with its mix of animation but maturity and I hope Dreamworks can continue making masterpieces such as this and that these guys are currently celebrating their victory at the box offices! SO PARENTS, KIDS AND TEENS PLEASE WATCH THIS FILM! IT IS GORGEOUS AND SO WELL-WRITTEN!!! I LOVED IT SO MUCH AND VERY MUCH MUST YOU LOVE IT TOO!!! :D

One of the best movies I've seen in a long time and maybe I'm biased because I struggle with my own mortality and death but it does talk about this topic in a way that not only reignited my own passion for life but also covered themes and topics I feel many people can resonate with in a way that is easy to digest and sit with. The animation is beautiful, something I hope Dreamworks carries on for more cartoony movies in the coming years, and is very colorful and atmospheric when it needs to be. The 'bad guys' all correspond with differing antagonist tropes in ways that feel seamless allowing them and their stories to not overlap in ways that feel forced, not to mention we get to see the classic Shrek2-esque spin by taking known fairytales and giving them modern twists. Extremely excited to see where Dreamworks goes from here and with El Gato con Botas.

This movie is an absolute masterpiece. 
Like, I aint gon lie. . . however, the movie perfectly contains sum form of social critisism. In the beginning, we can see Puss going to that ol lady and living a normal live, where the lady and the house represent current society and its function to keep its ppl safe, as it is also somehow shown in Hobbes social contract. More over, it shows that living autonomous life means to know oneself and take on burdens n stuff. So we see on that lil map that everyone has to go a diff path, since everyone has to live their own lifes the way it beneftits themselves the most. but what i think makes the movie special, is that ur not alone on youre path and that your path is not always seperate from the others but that there is lots of intersections. 
What i find most interesting about the paths is the goal of it. Youre said to be granted a wish, if u finish ur path. However, what i think the movie ist trying to say is that wishes/short cuts are for lil pussies. The goal of the path is not ur goal, but to find your meaning. The goal of the path is in a sense the beginning of your life. wich can also be seen in puss' path. Theres a stop where he's trapped in that lil hole an with his past lifes and the death. The Station is calles lost souls or smth. U can think that it only means "lost lifes" or smth. But i think what the movie is trying to say is that unless you find your own goal in life(reach the goal of the map path thing) ur lost. This is seen by the introduction of death. He said something like puss was hiding from death in more life. From running away ur basically lost, since your life has no meaning. Therefore the goal of this path is to find urselfe and your goal, what u want. Thats why that girl and her bear family had to visit a replica of their old home. 
what fascinates me about that scene is that the map says to look forward.But looking forward shows ur past, meaning that to be able to take steps in life u have to know where u came from and who u are. Thats sum crazy stuff ngl. 
Lastly, I wanna finish of with the Death. Obviously, the coolest character in the film, since he got cool swords and a badass design. However, he is not a acting character in the film, he's just the visualisation of the death. So he doesn't kill, but jus is there to show that death is there(?) if you know what I mean? 
He's the character that said that puss was hiding in life. What I find cool about him is not the usual talk, that u can only worth ur life when u know death. This film is greater than that. It is trying to close the binary between Life and Deaht. It is trying to show us the hierarchy that we've created, that life > death. But dont understand that both live from one another...
So its not that life n death are two different things, but that life inherits death and death life. In the sense that stuffs kinda mixed up: Life isnt just the absence of death. But death is the thing that makes life worth... oh wow ok it is the typical stuff, but i gotta say that the way it was portrayed was super cool. Or maybe it is different. When i watched the film, i remember that i understood it differently. Im sorry Im a lil tired.

Hilarious but serious when it needed to be serious. I didn't watch the original Puss in Boots and I've forgotten the plots of the Shrek sequels, but it was enjoyable and not confusing at all. You could take your kids to see this without having to rent the entire Shrek franchise for them beforehand. I like how the animation was more cartoony, stepping away from the uncannily realistic style of past Shrek movies. The voice acting was also great. Every character has a pretty distinct accent but not to the point where it feels mocking or grating, and the celebrity voice actors don't feel like they're just there to pull in a bigger audience. The theme of the movie, that we can't escape from death but shouldn't spend every moment fearing it, is something I needed when I was younger. Too many family movies are afraid to talk about death, so I enjoy the recent trend in animation where this topic is thoroughly addressed instead of avoided. Overall, a great movie made with heart, and a sequel that isn't a soulless cash grab.

Surprisingly delightful entry in the franchise thanks to a superb vocal cast, rich story and gorgeous animation.  Antonio Banderas remains superb in the title role, this time giving a rich performance as Puss is now in fear of death despite years of heroics.  He is matched by the rest of the cast, particularly Selma Hayek at Kitty Softpaws and Florence Pugh as Goldilocks.  Behind the camera, directors Joel Crawford and Januel Mercado direct a rich story dealing with death and what it means to live.  They also use the allegory of a wish effectively, showing how all those seeking it already have what they want already if they would just look for it.  It is matched by some gorgeous animation, blending CGI with 2D in a brilliant way, making for some fantastic action and set pieces.  All in all, a fantastic film and one of the best of 2022.

Easily the best animated movie of the year. The story  is surprisingly mature, with Puss struggling with his  mortality and it's not shying away from shocking scenes or heartwrenhing moments. The animation is stellar, Spiderverse's influence on modern animation is nothing other than magical. Plus the movie is really funny just like you would want it it from a Shrek movie! I'd say, this is the best movie in the Shrek saga since Shrek 2. And I can't wait for more of the franchise in the future.
"it was perfect, perfect, down to the last minute details"-Homelander

Here it is, the masterpiece I've been waiting for the last few years. Finally, someone reminded the giant studios how movies are made. The animation is incredible. DreamWorks decided to change the style of the cartoon for the better and they succeeded. The comic book style of "Spider-Man: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" and a bit of anime animation wink at the cat. The cartoon has enough morals. So you will have a lot to think about after watching it. And the main antagonist is one of the best antagonists in cartoons in general. His movements, look, and charisma make you scared. The sequel does not depend on the events of the first part and the series of Shrek cartoons. It tells a new story on its own, about a well-known fairy-tale character who, having spent his 8 lives, is afraid to lose his last one, running away from death itself. Visually, the cartoon is bright and fabulous. It was very unexpected that the director of the failed projects Trolls and The Croods: A New Era" Joel Crawford, was able to make this masterpiece and wipe Disney's nose. So I recommend it to everyone.

One of the cinematic masterpieces by Dreamworks. Great character development for Puss. Immersive action scenes. Magnificent camerawork. Just..absolute (chef's kiss). Character design is goddamn. The illustrations are so good too. I just-- damn.

My absolute favourite part of the movie was when Puss had a disagreement with his past 'souls'. You can see his distinctive personality change; he's still Puss, but wiser. Also, should I elaborate on how much I love the Wolf? He's such a remarkable character amongst all Dreamworks characters. There are multiple messages conveyed, plus the executions on the delivery are subtle and "just right". There are some predictable cliche tropes/plots at some turns but they are done "just right" as well by Dreamworks; tbh I'm fine with it. I also love how Dreamworks started to produce such gorgeous movies ever since the phenomenal Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse. All in all, I'm looking forward to more great movies by Dreamworks.

Never have I seen a movie portray anxiety and fear in such a realistic and immersive way. As a 17 year old who struggles with anxiety, I must say it resonated with me in a way I was not expecting. Side note: The new animation is great, the colours blend so beautifully and everything feels more cartoony and exciting.

The sequel turned out to be the same as Puss in Boots: risky, but able to win success. This is one of the best animation sequels of all time, everything is perfectly calibrated in it: from the absence of plot holes or their explanation, to the disclosure of characters, graphics, sound design. I really liked that all the references are unobtrusive. Except, of course, the scene after the ending, but it was made that way on purpose. 10/10, absolutely nothing to complain about. This kind of event rarely happens.

As the movie has relied heavily on word-of-mouth, I went into the theatre expecting a lot. Puss in Boots: The Last Wish delivered above and beyond my expectations with it's trademark self-aware humor dating from the Shrek franchise that has kept up with the times. 
However, what makes the movie a stellar contribution to cinema is the way it was able to, through its surprisingly imperfect hero, communicate mental health topics to viewers of all ages, and, in a 102-minute format, present a character arc of a depth and significance somewhere between Zuko (ATLA) and Wolverine (Logan).
An amazing achievement at reviving and modernizing a beloved franchise by DreamWorks and an absolute must-see.

I remember watching the first one and totally forgot what it was about by the time this movie came out. Didn't have any high expectations at first and wow was I in for a surprise. This film is my all-top favorite of 2022. The animation, the story, the characters. Nothing seemed shoehorned here. Even the Spanish lines --which I have little knowledge of -- didn't detract from my experience, but rather added to it. This _is_ a Spanish-based fairytale, so it makes sense. For me, the main villain in this film is the protagonist himself. Puss' own arrogance catches the attention of our supposed villain, Death disguised as the Big Bad Wolf, who gives Puss a "boot" of reality and makes him realize that he squandered his past 8 lives. The film does a great job of evoking fear every time Death appears on screen. The movie also tends to very effectively tug at your heartstrings here and there. One such moment is towards the end when Baby Bear thanks his sister Goldilocks for saving his life, and afterwards when they all give a heartwarming family hug. My favorite character has to be Perrito. He isn't exactly your average comic-relief as the film superbly depicts him as a supportive sidekick. He's an extremely likable character. Great, great film overall. I hope this does well in the box office because I would certainly like to see more subsequent films in this series!

Not just that, but talk about the animation style. Heavily inspired by "Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse (2018)", but made into something of their own, super awsome, super dynamic, and very cartoony.

I thought the first movie was "meh. okay." so I was expecting a fun-yet-mediocre sequel that hopefully wasn't too cringy. My mistake... this is one of those movies where the sequel is so much better than the original, and I loved everything about it. The updated animation style is awesome, the characters are all endearing and interesting (even the ones I thought would be annoying turned out to be great), the story is engaging and well written - and can I just say, both villains in this movie are incredible. A movie about heroes needs good villains, and where so many recent movies have failed, this movie succeeds big time. 

I was a bit nervous when I realized they were starting to follow the Marvel formula of "chase the glowy-thing" - but I ended up loving the concept of the Star Map and the deeper meaning it had towards revealing character motivations without every little thing having to be spelled out in an exposition dump. Simply brilliant storytelling. 

Animation continues to be one of my favorite mediums for storytelling. Maybe because it always feels more thought out. Maybe because the blend of humor, heart, and action, is more seamless in animation. Puss in Boots: The Last Wish truly stands out as spectacular, and I highly recommend it.

When i saw there was a sequel released to 'Puss in boots', i didnt think much of it, just like many other people (i assume at least). Man was this movie a HUGE surprise and honestly a fantastic expierence. The first is the visuals, wich are obviously fantastic, with inspirations from Spider Verse and a continuation of what Bad Guys first looked like. The colors pop and Puss looks better than ever before. The story is mainly about how puss has selfishly gone trough 8 of he's 9 lifes (how clever honesly) and now puss must take good care of his last live. This makes for a great foundation for character growth, and boy does he get trough that, mainly with the help of Death (yes, the litteral characterisation of the death) who is a wolf who follows puss around, making him nervous and anxious everytime he does hes signiture wistle. With other fairytales and nursery rhymes like goldilocks and the three bears and the main villian jack horner, everyone wants to have a map that leads to one wish wich can be whatever you want. We also see the return of kitty softpaws, who also get more development than ever. With the two main characters and the addition of perrito, wich is a lovely, way to optimistic dog serving as a great friend and character, they all fight for that last wish. I wont spoil the ending, but that might geniunely be one of the best endings ever to a film. This is a great movie that talks about important topics such a trauma, trust issues and the realisation you also one day will die, and that that thought is okay to have sometimes. A movie that has so little wrong that i cannot think of a single thing that geniunely bothered me or limited the expierence. Truly a near perfect movie, and that is insane to think about, but i am really happy that it is.

It was rated PG so I thought it would be ok for my kids. I didn't really see any witch craft. Just a magic star story. 
Then I was surprised by the language, the bleeping out of words. Making it normal for kids to hear. Then the violence that my kids had to turn away from. From an animated movie for crying out loud. Then I spotted a scene from when they looked at the map, I shouldn't had been surprised, but there was the all seeing eye placed on the map! Goodness! I refuse to allow my kids to be desensitized.
What should had been an innocent PG movie, turned to me having to keep explaining to my kids that the world just tries to see how far they can move the line. Which is why we have to protect our eye and ear gates.

I went to see Puss in Boots: The Last Wish with my fiancé and was expecting an average family movie, but I what I got was a beautifully animated film with amazing characters and themes. The movie tackles the heavy topic of death in a way that is appropriate and relatable for people of all ages and walks of life. My favorite parts of the movie were the antagonists, specifically how they use three different villain types without any of them clashing. Even as an adult, the wolf antagonist gave me chills. The relatable villain had an amazing redemption arc as part of the movie's B plot. I could say plenty more about Puss' character development, but I'll leave that to the movie itself. This movie is a must see!

This is one of the best movies i've ever seen and i just want you to know, if you havent watched this film yet, do it you wont regret it. 10/10 Masterpiece, The animation is flawless and reminds me a lot of spiderverse with some characters having smooth movement while the others have a slower fps, the battle scenes are really good and have a charm to them that if theres a battle scene, you know your gonna enjoy it.
now there are spoilers in this last section, so leave if you havent watched the movie yet. the characters are great and so is the character development, puss going from a fearless badass that "laughs in the face of death", to someone who is deeply scared of dying and losing his friends. now im gonna get this out of the way, death is an amazing character cuz he is always at the back of your mind like "what is that really scary death wolf that wants to murder puss doing right now while they fight or just talk" but there are thoose small reminders that, yes the plot should be moving, yes the plot is important, yes puss needs to hurry before he dies, and theese reminders come in the little whistle of death while he appears somewhere either behind or somewhere near puss. death really puts some emotional connection with puss and even the audience always fearing him, the fact that puss bleeds in the first interaction with death sets the boundaries of the film going forwards, like it isnt "this is a kid friendly cute chirldrens film" to "we arent scared of doing anything and you cant except the obvious". 10/10 film i dont usually do reviews but dang this movie is really fucking good. go watch it now

Handling its themes maturely without feeling overtly edgy, mainly just tastefully done if you will. Yes, I am indeed talking about the sequel to a spin-off of one of the most-memed movie franchise in pop culture. The dog sidekick felt like he might get annoying but seems to be the best take on the naïve sidekick in a film like this in a while. And the wolf antagonist, if your kids are easily frightened by a movie like Caroline not too long ago, maybe second guess bringing them, but if they handled that well and enjoyed that film overall, I encourage you to take them to see this. Puss in Boots is the perfect flawed role model. And what I said about handled "maturely", yes this movie has a message great for even the adults, maybe even especially so.

This movie's a must-see if you liked the first two Shrek movies (if you're really cool and have good taste). It expertly embodies the spirit Dreamworks had in its early days that made it special. The movie puts entertaining spins on familiar stories similar to the takes on fairy tale characters in Shrek, as well as creating a memorable plotline with interesting characters that reminded me of Kung Fu Panda's storytelling.

The movie's story is also surprisingly deeply mature. It tackles subjects like anxiety and valuing life in a way that's both intellectual enough to carry thoughtful messages and emotional enough to connect audiences with the characters and make you care about them.

There wasn't a single time in this movie where I regretted watching it or wished I was doing something else. It's fun, thought-provoking, and doesn't overstay its welcome.

This movie is absolutely AMAZING! The new art style seems fresh, and matches the movie very nicely.
Not only that, but the characters themselves seem new and exciting, with a more deep personality, while maintaining what makes them unique and special.
Both the protagonists and antagonists are well developed, and put together a show for the audience. There are no characters who feel "left out", with each and every one of them having enough screen time to make you connect and like them even more.
The humor and desperation are also mixed perfectly. No jokes are made out of place (and, believe me, the jokes in this movie will certainly make you laugh at least once), and the rush of every character, especially Puss in Boots while facing his main fear, is transmitted to the audience flawlessly.
Definitely a 10/10, and one of, if not the, best animated movie DreamWorks has ever made.

Now I'm definitely biased, as I loved "The Adventures of Puss in Boots" as a kid and watched it twice. But this movie is so cool. There are consistent themes of death, you can even see him in the background of some scenes. I love the art style. It's so bright and colorful, and you can even see the paint strokes. The story is heartwarming, although I believe the scenes with death are anxiety inducing and could be scary for young children. But I did love the references, like death putting coins over the eyes like the ancient Greeks. I was surprised by some scenes (like them going over each of Puss' deaths), but I really liked it. I think it's a good movie that shows how animation isn't just for children, and how adults can enjoy it as well. I hope more movies like this come out in the future.

🇧🇷 Eu devo começar falando da animação. Joel Crawford faz um ótimo trabalho ao mesclar 2D com 3D, trazendo o mesmo efeito visual de Homem Aranha: No Aranhaverso (2018). Gato de Botas trás o retorno triunfal de personagens que amamos como Kitty Pata Mansa (Salma Hayek), o protagonista Gato de Botas (Antônio Bandeiras), e nos apresenta a Perrito (Harvey Guillén) um cachorrinho abandonado que é impossível não se apaixonar, além de trazer a essência da DreamWorks e da Franquia Shrek novamente, brincando com contos de fadas e trazendo grandes referências e apresentando Cachinhos Dourados (Florence Pugh) e os Ursos, O Grilo falante e inclusive um vilão completamente arrepiante e macabro e que transmite medo. A Última vez que a DreamWorks fez isso foi em 2014 em Como Treinar o Seu Dragão 2 com Drago Sangue-Bravo. Gato de Botas 2: O Último Pedido é um presente para as famílias, crianças e fãs de Animação em 2023. Se você vai assistir em 3D, compensa muito. O Roteiro e a mensagem que o filme transmite são excelentes, e ainda vem com um musical divertido de se assistir e com uma surpresa incrível no final.

🇺🇸 I should start by talking about animation. Joel Crawford does a great job of mixing 2D with 3D, bringing the same visual effect as Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (2018). Puss in Boots brings the triumphant return of characters we love such as Kitty Pata Mansa (Salma Hayek), the protagonist Puss in Boots (Antônio Bandeiras), and introduces us to Perrito (Harvey Guillén) an abandoned puppy who is impossible not to fall in love with, besides of bringing the essence of DreamWorks and the Shrek Franchise again, playing with fairy tales and bringing great references and featuring Goldilocks (Florence Pugh) and the Bears, The Jiminy Cricket and even a completely creepy and macabre villain who transmits fear. The last time DreamWorks did this was in 2014's How to Train Your Dragon 2 with Drago Bloodblood. Puss in Boots 2: The Last Order is a gift for families, children and Animation fans in 2023. If you're going to watch it in 3D, it pays off a lot. The script and the message that the film conveys are excellent, and it even comes with a fun musical to watch and an incredible surprise at the end.

This was, simply put, a masterpiece that helps bridge the gaps between the realities of death and the general population. Puss in Boots: The Last Wish simply does an amazing job of teaching all audiences of every age the complexities and lessons that come with accepting one's own mortality.

Should've stopped, because whatever it is that made the films in the franchise released prior to this have life among its corporate, well-refined, but still vapid sense of parody humour is completely missing from this. True emotion, perhaps? Either way, this did not need to be created and it doesn't have a reason to exist to support everyone else's decision to think that it did. Without error. This is from the guy who has intentionally low standards for things to remain fair in judgment. I'm not just going to like this solely because it's a Shrek spin-off. The first film, I would do. This is a sequel for a spin-off film from 2011, and even that one was outdated because it was extending from a franchise in which most of its films were released in the 2000s. It was already outdated for the progression of culture, intolerable enough for reasons that aren't being a spin-off just by itself. Add to something outdated by itself, however, and it ends up like this, with there being no attempt at being real with anything anymore and realising that the public eye has grown less capable of critical thinking.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is a must-see film for fans of the beloved feline hero. The animation is stunning, the voice acting is top-notch, and the story is both action-packed and emotionally resonant. The filmmakers have done an excellent job of expanding on the characters and world established in the "Shrek" franchise, while still making the film accessible to new audiences. The humor is clever and appeals to both children and adults, and the themes of friendship and loyalty are beautifully portrayed. Overall, "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is a cinematic treat that should not be missed. 5 out of 5 stars.

Impression of PUSS IN BOOTS 2 --
Don't blow this off.  I know, I know, a week ago I'd never have thought I needed to see this kids' movie but everyone's been saying "It's incredible", "Best animated film I've seen all year" and "Best picture of 2022!" Got it.  Then they grab me, trembling, "If you don't see it in a theater you'll never forgive yourself!"  So I saw it and... good Lord, it's amazing!  I knew Avatar would be visually spectacular, but this little sequel, it's so funny, so innovative in its animation (Spiderverse has launched a revolution in jazz-like style), so engaging in a story that seems lighthearted at first but really tugs at you by the end.  I can't think of a moment that wasn't perfect.  That's right.  It's perfect.  I wouldn't change a single frame.
Every aspect of this fairy tale contributes, from evil Jack Horner (horrid freak) to Goldie and her three-bear crime family, but ever-on-his-heels (er, paws) is a bounty hunter with red glowering eyes that... I won't spoil it for you, but the film hints at Cervante's Don Quixote and his helper Sancho, valiantly trying to preserve himself, his model of being a hero, but the world is suggesting he's a relic.  There's a metaphoric death of the dashing swordsman, but something better is born.  All the while you're laughing at every scene.  It's a triumph.
Special mention goes to Perro, the little dog-dressed-as-a-cat helper (like Sancho Panza).  This side story of being yourself, winning by not opposing, victory by being incredibly naive or believing in the best at all times, it's a masterful stroke that adds to this ridiculously stunning work of perfection!  Perro's animators and story writers should get Best Supporting Actor at the Oscars.  Now get to a theater before it leaves, you'll be begging everyone to see it as well!

With an animaton style continuing the great work of The Bad Guys and an emotional story about facing the one thing you can't beat, this movie appeals to both adults and children as a genuine tale of what it means to face your fears.

Every characters arc is excellent, from Puss and Kitty through to Goldilocks and the Three Bears.  Also an awesome antagonist which was the perfect representation of the fear most have.

The fact it made the kids laugh and be a little scared, without making them terrified, and made adults talk about whether they fear death means the story has resonated.

Watch it.  Again.  And again.  You will not be disappointed.
Awesome animation and a great message!  Well done Dreamworks!
Kids loved it (ages 8 and 6), and I was able to find some adult-centered humor as well. There were some parts that were a bit scary for the youngest, but she was able to troop through.

Core problem was the nightmare material in this movie for younger kids (~7 and under).  The 2 villains are very dark, so much so that younger kids may cry during and get nightmares after watching.

Maybe your kid is old enough for this material, if so please disregard.  I have one 6 and one 10.  The 10 yr old enjoyed, the 6 yr old cried and is still freaked out of the dark now (wasn't before).  

Personally, I think DreamWorks scriptwriter should punch themself for this content.

Without giving away too much, the 2 villains are unstoppable embodied death (embodied as a stalker wolf with scythes) and a psychopathic murderer who shoots people.

Not sure what the creative team was thinking, but this seems unnecessarily dark and brooding.  The sociopath murderer was twisted, but the death wolf -- every time he appears, Puss (protagonist) has a panic attack.

As a fan of kids animation, there is a fine line where jokes / story may go over kids heads & is meant for adults, or times the kids get it and then have a lot of confusion trying to interpret.  This was pronounced here.  The moral of the story could have been delivered without traumatizing the youngest in the audience.

I've spoken to other parents, some had to take their youngest kids crying out of the theater, many had to deal with crying scared kids & try to sit thru the movie.

When I went to watch this movie I had high hopes. When I walked out of the theater I found my hopes blown out of the water. During the first action sequence I was taken aback by the quality of the animation. For me, the animation was most similar to what I had seen in Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse, but it was executed in such a unique way by alternating between being animated on 2's for the action sequences and being animated at full fps for the dialogue and subtle interactions. The fight choreography and dynamic camera movement, while being chaotic, never left my eyes wondering where to look. 

In terms of the story, it approached complex and difficult questions, like the concept of mortality and the value of your own life, or what it means to be family, and it served me the answer with ketchup and fries. It made big questions easy to understand. The topics and themes were definitely mature, but would still be understandable for younger audiences.

Each of the characters were as unique and interesting as I've come to expect from Dream Works. The Last Wish really shows the difference between a "Villain" and an "Antagonist".

On a less positive note, it seems the furries have gotten attached to the wolf character... Oh, well.
Big Jack Horner is the greatest villain in the history of film.

The animation, the writing, the direction. Everything falls in place so perfectly. My only issue is that we didn't really get to see much more of Goldilocks' relationship and issues with her family. It felt like it was squished in there near the end. It had a good build up but they didn't spend enough time on the actual conflict. Other than that, this movie is beautiful. It handles the character development in such a mature way. Puss struggling to deal with his anxiety and fear of death is written so well. I know I wasn't the only one to start crying during the scene where he has a panic attack. As someone who struggles with anxiety it felt so much more accurate than a lot of the depictions I've seen before. I hope DreamWorks continues to produce movies like this. 9.7/10

It ever so quickly changes from another film of a funny loveable cat to a touching story as we witness Puss try to escape his fate after taking his lives for granted, 
to try and escape death is to live a life of denial land fear. We experience the beauty of life not in spite of, but because of our inevitable morality. The world can be horrid and people can be disgustingly cruel, but it's the relationships and adventures we embrace that makes living worthwhile, to enjoy the rewards of being loved we must submit ourselves to the mortifying ordeal of being known.

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a phenomenal movie, for any audience old or young. I was entertained throughout the whole duration of this film, from the story, characters, set pieces and the superb animation. I was also surprised at how they tackled the topic of anxiety and it's effects, something you would not expect from a children's movie. As someone that has dealt with anxiety for most of their life, a lot of scenes hit close to home for me and I have to say it was handled perfectly. This movie is full to the brim with emotional moments, high octane set pieces and fight choreography that rivals the likes of anime shows like Demon Slayer. I cannot recommend this movie enough, and hopefully it will leave a lasting impression on you as it has done so for me

Movie of the YEAR. The emotions this movie made me feel I just did not expect from a puss in boots movie. A MUST watch film.

Por primera vez en más de una década,
DreamWorks Animation presenta una nueva
aventura en el universo de Shrek. Aunque la trama
es muy predecible logra entretener y no aburrir al
espectador en ningún momento. Creo que más que
la trama es la animación con tintes de historieta la
que logra esto,muy parecido a lo visto en spiderman
a New universe (2018) de Sony.
Me gusto ver de regreso a este personaje con
muchos guiños a historias de cuentos de hadas y
del universo de Shrek.
Maneja temas maduros cómo la muerte y el trauma
infantil de una manera muy ligera para un niño,
además de contar con los personajes y villanos
bien desarrollados.
Nos dejá con una gran lección sobre la vida y la
muerte algo muy parecido a Pinocchio (2022) de
Guillermo del Toro.
Creo que no es una película innovadora pero que
funciona para disfrutar en familia.
La volvería a ver un domingo cuando este
disponible en alguna plataforma de streaming, pero
mientras tanto,estaré esperando el siguiente
movimiento de DreamWorks sobre el universo de
Shrek.

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a long wait, 11 years, from the first movie, and it feels like the narratives and comedy of Dreamworks has matured as you would expect it to in that time. Gone are the cheap bits at shock humor that haunted Shrek entries and especially tone-deaf in the Kung Fu Panda trilogy, replaced with mature humor that will strike a note with audiences of all ages. Similarly, the narrative has grown up, a thrilling tale of confronting one's own mortality and the fear of death itself. This movie takes risks not only in its animation style, but its plot and humor as well, and every single gamble Dreamworks made paid off 100 fold. Watch this movie.

Una película excepcional, el nuevo diseño gráfico es muy eficaz, la buena historia y guion hacen que la trama se sienta fluida y se te pase rápido aún habiendo visto la cinta más de una vez. Todos los personajes mantienen una química enorme y una personalidad bien definida, se ve como todo encaja a la perfección y acabas teniendo una gran película animada, apta para todos los públicos. La historia va mucho más allá de hacer un par de bromas, tiene mensajes que hablan sobre temas y valores muy maduros como por ejemplo: el miedo a la muerte, el saber valorar lo que tienes en tu vida, disfrutar de tu vida de manera feliz y despreocupada, etc. Cabe destacar los distintos tonos que se muestran a lo largo de la historia, y aún así lo bien que se expresan las emociones de los personajes en todo momento, sobre todo las del protagonista, haciendo que la audiencia entienda que es lo que está pensando y sintiendo con tan solo una mirada. Además la cinta cuenta con una banda sonora muy pegadiza y activa, que te hará bailar al más puro estilo de "la leyenda", El gato con Botas. En resumen, una película maravillosa muy acertada en todos los aspectos cinematográficos, para mí la mejor que he visto en mucho tiempo.

It's an excellent movie, and without a doubt, one of my top 5 of all time movies, and easily in my top 3 movie of 2022, and here's a hint, it's not third nor second place.

The best animated movie to have come out in 2022. The last movie I had thought was fine, around a 2.5/5, but this movie absolutely blew me away. My biggest complaint was that it wasn't long enough, as it had so much going for it that I felt there were many things I wanted to be fleshed out more thoroughly. The visuals are amazing; think Into the Spiderverse combined with Shrek, but in a good way that makes it feel grounded and realistic but still with color and style that pop out like a comic book cover, yet for the whole movie. The plot was also very engaging; I felt interested the whole time. And the biggest thing for me was how the movie felt comfortable having more mature concepts in a kids movie, which I remember when  I was 7-10 years old I loved seeing in movies, and a young relative who also watched it agreed with me on that too. It wasn't completely flawless, but truly the pinnacle of what kids movies can be.

The Wishing star is a symbol of the "fantasy" that occupies a place in everyone's heart. Because life is not perfect, we fantasize about immortality, we fantasize about never being apart, we fantasize about never being defeated. Many of us spend our lives in vain for this fantasy, but we don't stop to look around us. What is the beauty and truth that is neglected?

Death, loss and failure are all things that we have to go through in our life. This story about the omnipotence of Wishing star and the non-existence of Wishing star tells us that nothing can help us avoid all these things. We can only accept, face and adapt to them with the spirit of our heart. The beauty of fantasy may not be so good, but the real beauty may be in the present, perhaps it is not too late, waiting for your discovery and embrace; Abandoned heart, insatiable, will come back to bite you.

An absolutely amazing film that's one of if not the best animated movies to come out in the past several decades. The Last Wish takes the surprising oppurtunity to tackle the struggles of life and death, managing to depict and do both justice with the tact they deserve while bringing us along for a ride that's entertaining and relatable to all ages. And along for the showing are some of the best villains I've seen make a debut in a kid's show in decades, managing to encompass several antagonists that are truly evil, either misguided, or forces of nature without any feeling left out or underdeveloped. 

The Last Wish was clearly made by people who cared and a team of writers who wanted to do Puss justice, and they succeed in making an absolute must watch movie. You could even go so far as to easily make the arguement that it surpasses the Shrek movies which spawned it.

Going into this movie I thought it was going to be a quick cash grab but it feels like such a passion project. The animation is beautiful, the storyline is fantastic, the character design is gorgeous and overall it's hilarious. I think it's my new favorite of all time and I recommend everyone at least gives it a chance.

It's almost ridiculous how good of a movie this is, especially after the first Puss in Boots movie was largely forgettable. The animation is great, with the action and art style taking on an aesthetic reminiscent of Spider-man: Into the Spiderverse at times. Said animation might look a bit choppy at times, but it helps to sell the over-the-top nature of some really impressive action pieces.
Aside from that, the story's pretty good and surprisingly emotional at times, and even contains some intense moments that could almost pass for light horror (no surprise that these tend to happen when the wolf character see in the trailers appears). Without giving anything away, the story also has a good message about life itself that's a good takeaway from the whole movie.  There's still plenty of funny moments, but don't go in expecting it to be a full-on comedy like the past Shrek movies and spin-offs.

All in all, I had a great time with this, and I also recommend seeing this on the big screen if you can. Hopefully this is the start of a good upswing in Dreamworks' animated library.

Amazing writing. It's rare to watch an animated film that actually has a story relatable to both adults and children, and Puss in Boots The Last Wish does just that. For starters, all the voice-overs were outstanding, and all of the characters had something to offer than just their presence in the story. The characters and the story itself had moments of joy, laughter and tears. The humor was particularly relatable and funny, again, for both adults and children. The pacing was spot on and the 102 minute runtime just flew by. This is one of the better animations I've seen in a while, and I love how the ending lead up to the next sequel to Shrek. A must watch for everyone.

No joke an absolutely incredible experience, as well as fresh and stunningly gorgeous. The animation style is very similar to "Spider Man: Into the Spiderverse", but is also significantly different enough to mean something else to the audience.

So many creative choices that span across the whole movie, and creative choices that stick to certain scenes, are incredibly well-done and lovable. The choice to personify death is one of my favorite villains of all-time; and he is so well done it legitimately brings me to tears. The scene where Puss in Boots is fleeing from the Cave of Lost Souls and is comforted by Perrito, the choice to legitimately make a heart-wrenching and emotion-packed scene is so awesome when I know that adding a tension-relieving joke would have been so easy. 

But it's not all serious, after-all it is a kid's movie. But to call it a kid's movie is a strawman- it is so, so much more. The jokes are well-done and the references to pop culture ("Not the bees!") are both cringey and lovable; just how I like them. The wish plotline is a common trope, but is so well done in this movie through the incredible relationships between characters. Goldi and the Bears are a group that want the wish to have a family, but already have one. Kitty Soft-Paws wants the wish to trust someone, but through the journey she gains that naturally. Puss in Boots wants the wish to get more lives, and to make his glory-days last forever, but learns that this isn't what he truly wants. Jack Horner is a greedy doofus and genuinely has some great jokes, as well as serving alongside Death as a sort of "Time-Keeper". 

Incredible movie. The 10/10 rating is overdone but I legitimately think this movie was pulled off nigh-perfect, and is an incredible addition to the animated movies world.

Phenomenal movie! Excellent and unique animation style with awesome use of frame rate changes during fight scenes. Forget if you didn't like the first one, Puss in Boots 2 is miles ahead in every aspect from its predecessor. Some scary scenes that may not be the best for under 8 year olds

The animation style straight out of spiderman into the spiderverse are killing it! The story is great, considering its a sequel to puss in boots, which wasnt fantastic. The plotline with Kitty having trust issues is actually very well done, many movies, like for example "raya and the last dragon" these days try to feed it to you through a tube while screaming at your face "DO YOU GET THE MESSAGE?". Death as a character is one of, if not the best and most scary villians from dreamworks movies. In the first scene with him i had litteral chills when they showed Puss bleeding, i was not expecting them to show something like this in a kids movie,The idea that litteral death is trying to kill you, is terrifying. I expected to hate the supporting dog character, but i didnt. Its nice to see a such a positive character interacting with all those sad and bitter (for the most part) characters. His backstory was so tragic, it almost made me cry T_T.  Easily one of the best movies by Dreamworks. 12/10 would watch again

I'll get this out of the way first. This movie is fantastic. Plain and simple. It's great. It's creative, it's funny, it's touching, it's scary, it's mature, it's intelligent, it's entertaining for both kids AND adults, it's... A goddamn Puss in Boots The Last Wish. I think we can all agree that this is the last title anyone here can associate with top notch quality. I mean it's a sequel to a spin-off movie from over 10 years ago. A rather mediocre one at that. And yet this movie goes far and beyond ANY expectations and makes itself into probably THE best animated movie of 2022. But then again. This is coming from a studio that made Kung Fu Panda series be known as one of the finest animation series as well.

But let's get to the details. First being the animation. It's gorgeous. It's amazing how well this movie looks with it's Spiderverse like animation and further proves how chasing after realizm in animated movies is at this point a fool's errand that kind of misses the point of animated movies. But it's not just a rip-off Spiderverse in looks. Oh no. When that movie looked like a comic book that came to life, this one feels like a Illustrated Fairy Tale book. The paint brush aesthetic looks great, it's colorful and feels alive. It's animated in a fantastic way and I think it's best described in saying that the fight with the Giant from the trailers is NOT the best part of this movie. Oh no. It only gets better from there. 10/10 on visuals.

Now to the characters. I love pretty much all of them. Puss in Boots of course takes center stage here and his character is at it's best here in terms of depth and humor. He is cocky bastard at first, but as he loses his next to last life he quickly gets humbled and reminded of his now very apparent mortality and his character goes through great amount of growth. It's very nice to see his character evolve like it does in this movie. Another stand out I say is the Wolf who I can already tell will give several children nightmares (and that's good, you know a good fairy tale from the amount of scarred children it leaves in it's wake). People that made this DO NOT hold back with how scary they make this character. He is by far the best thing in the movie from his fights, the change in mood whenever he appears and the music that accompanies him. He is definitely one of the best villains I saw in an animated movie (but I could argue if it's okay to call him one, but that would mean getting into spoilers). Other characters such as Kitty Softpaws, Goldielocks, Three Bears, Jack Horner and Perrito are all VERY fun as well. Goldie and her family are a very sweet family that go through their own journey in this and could be said they are deutragonists of this movie, I really enjoyed them, their chemistry and their sweet development. Jack Horner though... I say this. He is by far the funniest part in this movie. He is a bastard, plain and simple and he is hilarious because of it and a certain character that is alongside him for a good chunk of the movie. As for Kitty, it's very nice to see her back and her story tied with Puss is very interesting and I like how they do not linger too long on her drama with Puss and resolve it in a more real way that doesn't derail the movie in any way. And then there is Perrito who many probably thought was going to be an annoyance, but he is by far the Heart of this movie and he is involved in probably the most touching scene in the movie. You will know when you see it. All in all characters another 10. It's incredible how there are so many of them and all of them are fun and likeable in their own way.

The story itself is very simple. It's a race to get the Last Wish from a fallen star. It's as Fairy Tale-ish as you can get. But the way it's executed, the way each character changes (well most of them at least) on this journey and how imaginative and creative the setups and environments are make it feel fresh and it really leaves an impact on you. Don't be fooled by the marketing. This movie deals with VERY heavy subjects such as death, mortality and appreciating one's life and acceptance of Death. It's a heavy movie in terms of themes, but it's so great to see that with it, it still is a very entertaining movie. With many clever jokes, great pacing, fantastic music (oh my God the music is GREAT in it as well. Heitor Pereira did a A+ job here) and colorful world and characters. It is a movie that can be enjoyed by people of all ages and that is something that is so good to see today. And this movie VERY well utilizes it's PG rating. Kids NEED Parental guidance in this movie, it is not a movie you put on to shut them up. You put it on because you want to show them something great, something they can have fun with, be scared of and learn from. And I think a lot of adults can sympathize with struggles characters face in this movie and laugh at the more adult jokes as well. Overall from story standpoint it's also 10/10. It's not a new story or message, but it is told in a way that makes it FEEL new and fresh and it tackles it in a mature way.

As for flaws... Ehhhh... Hard for me to find really. To me it's as perfect as animated flick can get. Again PUSS IN BOOTS THE LAST WISH. God is this a weird thing to say. Maybe there are some pacing issues with Goldie's story and her family conflict being resolved quickly during climax and one character is pretty damn 1-dimensional, but I would argue it's to add to the comedy and charm of said character since that one is not meant to be seen as anything more serious. It is not one the same level of greatness as Prince of Egypt obviously, but as far as Shrek movies go or most Dreamworks movies go... or hell, most animated movies go overall it's pretty damn close to the top to me. In Shrek franchise it's on the same level as Shrek 2 to me and it's a high, HIGH praise.

I have to say. I always preferred Dreamworks over Pixar. Yes, they do have FAR lower lows than the animation juggernaut, but to me they had higher highs with movies such as Prince of Egypt or Kung Fu Panda movies (and the fact that I can say Kung fu Panda series is one of the best pieces of animation is hilarious) and I found their good movies to be far more rewatchable than Pixar ones. But since then they kind of went down with quality sadly, but recently with The Bad Guys and now this movie I think it's safe to say that they are officially back and maybe better than ever. This movie I think proves how great movies from Dreamworks can be today and I think if they keep on going in this direction we may get more VERY special movies from this studio. And I wish them the best of luck on this road and for this movie to become greater and greater success, maybe even winning an Academy Award (as meaningless as that became as of late).

What can I say anymore it's about 9.5 to 10/10 to me. I love it. And I think many people will love it as well. Probably not to the same degree as me, but I think this will make your day and the new year that much better. It's worth your money, it's worth your time, it's worth your attention and by all means it's worth watching more than once.

The movie sort of glorifies murderousness so it was rough seeing little girls in fairy tale dresses watching the movie.  However for an adult or late teen, the movie is really enjoyable.  Other than the usual cast of characters, goldilocks kind of steals the show.  My nine year old enjoyed it but the content was not appropriate for her in my conservative opinion.  TV-14

It's an awesome show. The animation, the sound design and the scenery is outstanding. The plot and the execution of the story is just to die for. Moving, sad, happy, frightening, overwhelming, and calming each in their own scene. So many emotions throughout one story, and none of them felt forced or out of place.

[SPOILER WARNING]
Some specifics I especially liked:
- Death. The metaphor of death and the disliking of multiple cat lives embodied as a fearsome wolf on the hunt is one of the best ideas this movie could've used. The character itself, when looked back on, is blatantly obvious, but the viewer might not even know what they are facing until it's clearly told. Their ambition and hunt-thrill build a compelling obstacle character who isn't straight up evil. Their motif isn't inherently to kill Puss, but to punish someone who hasn't valued their life while they were thrown so many chances to do so. I respect that.
- Perrito. I don't even know where to start. Our pup is so blatantly traumatized they don't even notice it. The support they provide to anyone who crosses their path is amazing, especially since they've had noone who wanted them up until the movie's story. They also represent a part of quite a lot of people's life, where they rely on therapy animals to go about their days and be able to overcome anxiety attacks, get general emotional support, or maybe even thoroughly aided help, which a companion can provide. The scene where Puss had a meltdown and Perrito laid on them felt real in atmosphere, just as in accuracy, as anxiety aid companions often apply pressure to help the body calm down. I love what Perrito stands for.
- The animation. It is dynamic, it isn't a constant, and that's what makes it so compelling and satisfying to look at. The framerate constantly changes, the simplified special effects give an entire different tone to a scene, and the ever changing flashing colors make for an amazing environment which doesn't stop moving when a good fight comes up. The camera work is so well done, it's always clear to see what the power of the current shot is. As an animation nerd myself I bow to this cinematic masterpiece.

I've talked enough, all in all I can only recommend this movie.

It was a really phenomenal and very enjoyable DreamWorks animated family movie. It had really majestic animation, really amazing voice cast, really awesome action, really well done comedy, really thrilling adventure, really imaginative fantasy, very extraordinary music, really beautiful visuals and a really impressive plot. In my opinion, I think it’s one of my new favorite animated movies I’ve ever saw in theaters in my whole life. I really recommend this movie to both kid and adults.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" was one of the biggest surprises of 2022. This was not a movie that anyone was asking for, yet it was incredibly charming and fun. The film merges two animation styles, which are both gorgeous and cutting edge. There are moments of traditional DreamWorks animation and others that are similar to "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse".

The characters introduced in this film are reminiscent of those in the first two "Shrek" movies. Each character is carefully thought out, and evokes an emotional response, whether that be hope, fascination, or fear. From the confused Goldilocks to the adorable Perrito to the fearsome Lobo, everyone brings something new to the table.

There is honestly not a lot to criticize about "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish". The film hit darker notes than previous "Shrek" films and there were moments in the theater when kids shrieked. Some of the scenes are a little drawn out, but the story itself is strong.

For those with small children, be aware that there is a strong use of "hell" and some cleverly censored words throughout the movie. Otherwise, the film is perfectly appropriate (more than some other "Shrek" movies) for kids.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is the best animated film of 2022 and the best "Shrek" film since "Shrek 2" (not that the competition is very stiff). The animation is stunning, the voice-acting crisp, and the story is interesting for both children and adults. Even if you haven't seen the first "Puss in Boots", go and see this movie. You will not be disappointed.

Also, the new DreamWorks opening is excellent.

This movie was not what i was expecting, I thought it it was gonna be a generic side character movie like the first one was. This movie is on par with Shrek 2. I loved the antagonists and all the side characters like the dog perrito and Kitty Softpaws. I loved the main antagonists being Death and Jack Horner. Allthough i didnt know who the character "Jack Horner" was he was a very funny characters with his design and the way he acted with no regard for his goons. I also loved the way they described "Death" in this movie. They describe them as a scary character that has the motive of "Death will always find you" and "wherever you run i will always find you". This movie also has alot of character development, for example the protagonist; Puss In Boots is shown at first as an egoistic self centered person who sees himself like a living legend who doesnt fear death. But later when he dies and is down to his last life he encounters actuall death and is scared for his life running away, and as described in the movie, always comes back for him. This was probably one of the best animated movies i've ever seen.

BUT OH MY GOD I LOVED THE WOLF. LITERALLY one of my favorite anganonists/villains of all time. he had such a relaxed and cold personality no fear just confidence in what he could do. he wanted to teach puss in boots to value your life and do be grateful. and once he understood he backed away, then pus and him agreeded that they would meet again because is death "straight up". the wolfs distant whistle such a simple tune is like death slowly creeping up. i loved jack horner too, he had such an amazing and funny design and personality. perito (the dog) was so cute too i loved pusses new start with kitty soft paws. overall such an amazing movie and it made me cry honestly, very funny as well.

I was skeptical for a plethora of reasons about this movie. I've liked the past installments, and even the TV series was ok. But this movie literally blew me away. The story is fantastic, the character development is realistic. The connections seem are genuine and heartwarming. 
And the action...oh my god...the "choreography" of each action piece was outstanding, and the handling of each characters strengths and weaknesses were fantastic. Even the payoffs to goofy plot devices like Perrito learning dough eyes was well used. The antagonists and villains were so spot on. And the bounty hunter arch was amazing. The first few scenes were so fantastically done that I didn't think it would keep it up through a few sections, but it just kept being amazing. 
It really feels like the producers were told to just make a good movie, and that's what they were done. I don't feel the hand of the studio in this at all, just an amazingly well done animated film. And an absolute see in the theaters experience, as well.
The low frame rate, Spiderverse style animation moments made me feel like they were going to try to pointlessly capitalize on that style, but they really utilized it to elevate the action sections, even using the style to contrast standard animation motion to push parts of the narrative and character development. Fucking SPLENDID film.

Death himself was one of the greatest villains in animation history even when he only has a few actual confrontations with puss as he perfers to watch from the shadows with his red eyes and honestly horrifying to the bone tune 
The other villain is the goldilocks crime family, who while at first seemed out of place definitely fit in near the end, being a mix of comic relief and evilness, while it was quite easy to determine how their story would play out and end they were still a great addition to the story 
All in all puss in boots 2 is a great film that isn't scared to go pass the limits of a "children film" and become actually scary at times while having actual character development for a talking cat

This movie was amazing, life changing if you will. I was raised watching the original puss in boots movie. It was so dear to me. So when I heard there was going to be a sequel I hoped and hoped it would live up to the expectations of my childhood. WELL IT DID. the animation is beautiful and full of life. It's colorful and doesn't feel synthetic or corporate like the latest disney movie animation has been. The jokes are actually funny. There are definitely a few jokes only adults would understand and they used very very mild curse words but it works! The dialogue fits the movie in my opinion and I loved how they also used a lot more spainish in this movie! They also made sure there wasnt english subtitles so those jokes are only for the spainish speakers in there hehe (me included lol). The characters were also really good, none of them annoyed me which is suprizing because usually in cartoon movies there is some kind of side kick or something that just gets on my nerves but there wasnt any in this movie! The character design is one of my favorite aspects of the movie. And the jabs at Disney were really funny aswell. The story also really hit home and made me tear up a bit since I deal with some of the things that were talked about in the movie (spoiler?: mostly puss's anxiety of death and living up to his "legend" also the therapy dog reminded me of my cat who is kind of like my therapy animal lol). Anyways the story was 10/10, everything was 10/10 and I would definitely watch it over and over again. And I hope DreamWorks continues making great sequels and movies like this!!!

Where do I even begin. I walked into the theater expecting a mildly interesting action adventure movie about a talking cat wearing boots and I was pleasantly surprised. This movie is absolutely amazing, and I don't say that lightly. For starters, the writing for the characters was simply outstanding. When I saw that there was many characters, I was worried that some of the characters would be tossed to the side a little too easily and that others would receive too much spotlight but no! Each character had depth and added something interesting to the movie. I didn't dislike a single character and not once did I feel like any character under/overstayed their welcome. I also enjoyed the humor. Many movies targeted towards children nowadays just use crude, unfunny humor to try to appeal kids but this movie is actually funny. The jokes don't feel forced and I found myself audibly laughing at many gags. The animation left me speechless. It was incredible. Not a second of screen time was wasted and every frame was vibrant and full of life. Some scenes, you could see every hair on Puss's face and on others, unshed tears glistening in his eyes. The style was definitely inspired by Spiderman: Into the Spider-verse but didn't feel like a copy. The film takes that comic book style and warps it into its very own unique version. The paintbrush aesthetic adds so much color and depth to each scene, giving the viewers some amazing scenery. The fight scenes were action packed and well choreographed. During many of them, especially during Puss's final fight with Death, I could feel my heart pounding in anticipation. Will he win, will he loose? The fights keep you entertained and on your toes, it's outrageously good. While the plot felt a little simple, it feels intentional so that the movie can focus more on the compelling characters and settings. The forest where most of the movie takes place is such an interesting concept, the landscape changing depending on who was holding the map led to some great animation and ideas. The movie took a huge risk with three main antagonists and it thankfully, pulls it off well! I adored Goldilocks relationship with the three bears and her emotional inner turmoil was a great addition to the story. I also enjoyed John Mulaney's role as Jack Horner and while he did feel like the weakest villain, he makes up for it by being incredibly funny. I don't even know how to describe the third antagonist, the wolf, who was the embodiment of death. The wolf was genuinely scary. His bright red eyes standing out against the darker tones of the scenes he was in was so visually pleasing. Watching death himself stalk Puss the entire movie was chilling and compelling. From the very moment he appeared on screen, I could tell he was going to be one of the best parts of the movie. Watching Puss run away from the fight and have a full blown panic attack in the woods truly showed the audience just how much of a threat the wolf was. The movie didn't treat the wolf like a joke and didn't present him lightly. He is death. I don't mean that metaphorically, or rhetorically, or poetically, or theoretically, or any other fancy way. He is death. This review is crazy long and I am starting to ramble so I will end this with an overall rating. 

Humor- 9.5/10
Characters- 9.5/10
Plot- 8/10
Animation- 10/10
Overall- 9.5/10

I like the conceit of two cats and a dog traveling together, learning from one another... At first the cats (crafty, combative, suspicious) cannot believe how gullible and foolish this "ridiculous" dog is... but in time they learn to be a little more doglike (trusting and affectionate) and he learns to be a little more catlike (savvy and discerning). It's nice :)

I like the physical gags, eg, where the anthropomorphic Puss in Boots reverts to his base feline nature. I like the character design of Goldilocks and The Three Bears. I think it's visually beautiful much of the time.

Most of all I love the bold, Thoreau-ean message, beautifully manifested into a literal fight sequence at the end of the film: that we must learn to cherish, defend, and embrace-- with passion and without fear-- the one short and precious life we have, and stop passively wasting our time away, wishing for an easy fix.
