How do I even get started with how extraordinary and awesome this movie is. It was beyond everybody's expectations. In all aspects, the animation, art style, action, story, characters and development was Top Notch. But what so impressive about this movie that stood out to me was the immense Depth, meaning, and emotions ingrained inside it. This movie isn't just a kids film, it has deep spiritual meaning. And I am sitting there blown away by the scenes and wondering if anybody else is getting it too? 
The character death is a manifestation of Puss's fear and anxiety collected over his past lives. In this journey, his old identity went through a whole breakthrough and he had to face his fear which he has avoided for all his lives. It was pretty summed like a Dark of night the soul? Then there was the character Perrito which really shines through the story, whom was the exact epitome of innocence, joy and purity? Even after going through such a tremendous sorrows, he was still vastly unaffected and is able to keep an attitude of unwavering positivity and lightheartedness? That, truly, is a character of enlightened nature. I feel that his had so much to teach all of us, that despite whatever that happens to us, it was perception that created our reality.

I made a Rotten Tomatoes account just to gush about how phenomenal this movie is. Not only is it stunning visually, but the story tackles incredibly deep and profound topics. I never would have expected a Puss in Boots sequel of all things to be about panic and anxiety and existential dread. Every character is given just enough development for the purpose they serve without feeling like they are overdeveloping someone, or ignoring someone who needed more depth for the part they play. This movie was full of characters, and the fact that they managed to somehow neatly place them all into the story baffles me as an aspiring writer. The wolf is obviously incredible and horrifying. His presence mixed with Puss's fear, amazingly brought to life by the character animation, puts you right into the scene with them. Even Perrito is a fantastic addition to the cast. Making him the only character who frequently curses is a hilarious subversion. I also think that Jack Horner is really funny. I haven't seen him talked about as much but I find his irredeemably cruel personality really great, especially since it fits the whole -death- theme of the movie. Please go see it in theatres, I could go on and on about every aspect but it's better if you see it yourself.

I know what you're thinking. "Puss in Boots 2? The sequel to that mediocre movie about the funny little cat from Shrek that came out over a decade ago?" My entire family laughed at me when I told them I was going to see Puss in Boots 2 in the theater. But please trust me when I say that this movie is a masterpiece for kids and adults equally. Nothing I say can prepare you for how unironically and extraordinarily good this film is. I cannot believe it hasn't even grossed a tenth of what Avatar: The Way of Water has worldwide. We need to support this movie so that Dreamworks understands that we see it and that we want more like it.

On the surface, it may seem like a quaint little movie about Puss and the frankly generic hero's struggle with overcoming an inflated ego, but it's so much more than that. Without giving away too much, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish dives headfirst into very emotionally mature topics in a way that I seldom see in movies- animated or otherwise. Throughout the film, Puss grapples with the reality of mortality, and it's genuinely terrifying and impactful.

I feel like this movie really showed off how animation is a medium that deserves respect. There are some aspects of this movie that just wouldn't work in a live-action film, and I adore that. The exaggerated anatomy during fight scenes, a certain red-eyed wolf villain, and the incredible character acting are all things that I can't imagine being executed as flawlessly as they did in the limitless medium of animation. The painterly brush strokes in the environment and characters really fit the fairytale genre. I was just blown away by the beauty packed in every single frame.

The fact that the pacing was so flawless despite there being 3 main villains and 3 main protagonists to give appropriate amounts of screentime was absolutely insane. At no point did it feel like we spent too long or too little on one character, and everyone's motives and actions felt in-character, justified, and well thought out. To me, this is what cinema is. This is what it's all about. Not a wasted shot, not a wasted line, not a wasted second. Perfect intention in every moment. Every second is dense with beautiful visuals and rich storytelling.
The best animated film for 2022. Trust me.

The animation films, of recent, have been too safe. They don't risk much, and therefore earn decent rewards in the box office.
This movie, however, was an incredible risk. Reviving an 11-year dead franchise with a mediocre spin-off franchise's sequel film? That's nearly unheard of. And somehow, they made it work.
The Last Wish is the greatest representation of anxiety and PTSD I have ever encountered, and that's coming from someone with an anxiety disorder. Puss's anxiety attack was so real. His fear blinded him, and the comfort of those he was near to helped him through such a traumatic experience.
Again, the revival of the Shrek universe wasn't something I was looking forward to, but DreamWorks brought their A-game. The vibrant animation style, enticing soundtrack, well-written characters, and beautiful story is amazing.

Puss In Boots: The Last Wish is an absolute masterpiece! Never before have I ever been compelled to review a movie before, but this film was so good that I just had praise it! People need to go see it in theaters so that it succeeds in the box office. DreamWorks NEEDS to make more films like this one!

Spoilers below!

First off, the animation is stunning. It's stylized, similar to Spiderverse but with it's own flair. It has a very pastel like feel to it which greatly compliments the fairy tale theme.
The action is top notch! They purposely lower the frame rate during high action scenes. It helps to exaggerate the look of fast motion, and let's you feel the weight of blow. The choreography is great! The very first fight scene is very reminiscent of Levi fighting the titan on the rooftops in Attack On Titan, and the action only gets better from there.
This movie has not a single bad character somehow! Even the dog, who you'd think would be annoying, ended up being genuinely heartwarming and has funny moments. Never during the film was I disappointed to cut away to a different character because they were all good and all had an appropriate amount of screen time. The character arcs were compelling, the villains were incredible- I'll get back to the villains- not a single second of this film was spent on a character that brought down the experience.
This film has a lot of villains. You would think that with that many villains to juggle, the film would miss the mark, but no. It all balances out quite nicely! And they're all distinctly different from each other! Jack Horner is a hilariously irredeemable crime boss, Goldilocks and the three bears have a genuinely heartwarming message, and the wolf is by far the best animated villain I have ever seen! Maybe even the best villain period! If you have small children, this might not be a good film for them because the wolf is scary. And I don't mean that metaphorically, poetically, rhetorically, theoretically or any of that. I mean he is straight up scary.
This movie's themes about death and making the best of the time you have left on this Earth is handled really, really well and maturely. It has Puss having to come to grips that one day, he will die. Now that he's on his last life (since cats have nine lives), he has the fear death in him. Seeing him grow and realize that death comes for us all, and accepting that feels like a major and well deserved accomplishment.
While I absolutely adore this film, there are a couple cautionary warnings that I feel I have to express about this movie. While it is advertised for kids, it has a lot of darker themes, suggested swearing, morbid humor, and an intense villain that parents may not want to expose their younger children to. That said, if you think you're child is old or mature enough to handle some somewhat more intense themes and action, then this is a movie that both the parents and the kids will enjoy.

M A S T E R P I E C E

What a movie!! Where should I start? It tells a story of an arrogant, selfish adventurer, whose ego and carelessness led to him burning through 8 of his 9 lives, then going on a quest to get them back, and along the way, learns that he doesn't have to be the Legend, always alone, always being self-centered and egotistical. Puss goes on a journey to the Wishing Star, which will grant one wish to whoever gets to it first. He is joined by Perrito, a dog who, despite being treated like crap all of his life, is very upbeat and happy, and just a little too trusting for his own good, and he meets back up with Kitty Softpaws, his old flame, with some understandable trust issues. But they are not alone in the search for the Wishing Star, because there are 3 main baddies after our feline hero. First is Little Jack Horner, or rather Big Jack Horner, a giant psychopath bent on getting all the magic in the world. Next is Goldielocks and the Three Bears Crime Family, a smash-and-grab operation and a real family, as they took Goldie in and made her a part of their family. And finally, no fairy tale would be complete without Wolf, who may be more than just a bounty hunter. The movie is good, it's really good, it's really incredibly really good. The character development has really advanced in this movie, the story has some serious messages while also having lighthearted moments. They even swear in the movie(Don't worry, the really bad ones are bleeped out{Yes, the bleep sound effect is in the movie!) After 11 years, the Legend has returned. He's back, and better than ever. The character arcs are beautiful, with Puss, Kitty, and Perrito all going through noticeable changes throughout the entire movie. And there is a sub-plot with Goldie and the Bears, and Kitty too, involving themes of family and trust respectively. The movie doesn't dumb down the themes, not laying them out like a Thanksgiving banquet. It shows the themes, instead of telling them. Big Jack Horner was a genuinely funny villain, and even though he didn't have his own character arc, he was no less of a villain than the others. Over, the movie is exceptionally-great, with amazing animation, fun and complex, the stories are very compelling, with themes that are shown instead of told, like fear of death, appreciating your life, what family really means.

Being a fan of the "Shrek" franchise, I could not pass up the newest entry.  While "Puss in Boots:  The Last Wish" does have its problems, it is still a very well made and entertaining movie.  Antonio Banderas is perfect as the voice of the title character.  Salma Hayek is terrific also as the voice of Kitty Softpaws.  The supporting characters are clever and well done.  The character of Perrito (voiced by Harvey Guillen.) is also a welcome addition to the long list of comic sidekicks we see in these types of movies.  One other highlight is the character of Death (Voiced by Wagner Moura.).  The writers on this movie handeled the character very well.  The resolution with the character was quite good.  My only criticism of the movie is its rather formulaic storyline.  In the beginning of the movie, Puss only thinks of himself and could not care less about anybody else.  However in time he comes to realize his selfishness is wrong and he needs to change his attitudes towards others.  Nothing we have not seen before.  However this minor flaw is made up for by a well done climactic fight sequence.  It has just the right amount of thrills and does not become too drawn out or overblown.  Over two decades after "Shrek" Dreamworks is still able to keep the franchise going with some good entertainment.  If you are a Shrek fan as I am I think you would like "Puss in Boots:  The Last Wish".

I highly recommend this delightful film for all ages.

Puss is the perfect depiction of growing out of who you once were into something better, coming to terms with the fact that you need to cherish the one life you have with the ones you love. The pacing is just right with only one moment in the beginning feeling just a tad bit drawn out. Overall we had a lot of fun watching this film and finding our own ways to connect with the different characters in the film. I highly recommend this movie to everyone and we will definitely be watching it again

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is as spry and light on its feet as its titular feline. The inherently alluring paradox of the swashbuckling kitty from the "Shrek" universe remains firmly in place 11 years after his first solo feature. He's a dashing adventurer, a charmer with the ladies, feared and renowned throughout the land -- but he's also unbearably adorable as he laps up milk from a shot glass with his pinky, sandpapery tongue. As always, the charismatic and sensitive Antonio Banderas finds just the right tone in exploring this furry animated figure's suave and silly sides. "The Last Wish" expands the roster of ridiculously talented supporting players from the Oscar-nominated 2011 original "Puss in Boots." Joining Banderas and his longtime friend and co-star Salma Hayek Pinault are Florence Pugh, Olivia Colman, Ray Winstone, Da'Vine Joy Randolph, and John Mulaney, among many others. They bring a surprising amount of substance to what might have been a purely playful endeavor. But of course, the fast-paced humor and elaborate visuals are the main draws of director Joel Crawford and co-director Januel Mercado's film. The film's aesthetics may rely too heavily on anime influences, especially during the action sequences, but the vibrant colors and rich textures are a delight. From the moss growing on a fearsome forest giant to the shiny silkiness of Puss' whiskers blowing in the wind, "The Last Wish" offers a variety of eye-popping details. And it frequently features dramatic shadows and subtle dissolves to transition from past to present or one scene to the next. But the film also manages to convey messages of selflessness and teamwork in a way that doesn't feel heavy-handed or cloying. And the stellar voice performances and dazzling visuals keep things so engaging you won't need a laser pointer or a catnip-stuffed mouse toy to entertain you.

Overall, while I can't say I had loads of laugh-out-loud moments in this film like I enjoyed in the previous instalment or the Shrek Franchises, I'm proud to say I found this sequel went deeper, darker, and more adventurous than expected. Fans will see the adorable Puss at his worst but also at his strongest, which I loved experiencing on the big screen. Voice work is a knock-out, and the animation style feels like a classic fairy tale book coming to life for most of the duration, which is a nice, magical touch. Some younger audiences might be a little frightened by some dark tones. This animated film strikes strongly and positively like a fresh glass of cool milk.

"This is a fairytale."

The narrator states, matter-of-factly, in the beginning of the film. And of course you'd think a talking cat in boots fighting giant tree-stone monster while holding a concert is a fairytale, right? 

Because if you think so you're wrong. Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a surprisingly deep and relatable story about the meaning of death and of life. 

With a mix-and-mashed version of a few well-known fairytales, the writer showed audiences of all ages some otherwise done-to-death morals, that life is to be cherished, that the real wish is the friends we made along the way, to stop and smell the rose, etc. etc. They are, of course, not the main parts of the story, but they have set a heartwarming ambience to the narrative, and did so successfully, making it insightful even to an adult.

The central piece to the story, then, is Death's overarching pursuit for Puss in Boots. Character, animation, and sound designers reached for the best of the best in making the appearance of Death as horrifying as possible, because to Puss in Boots and possibly most of us, he is. Although he was personified in the film, the way different visual elements worked together still made it easy to interpret the story in a figurative way and read its moral that life is to be cherished.

The film's pace seems somehow rushed, but I don't see it being a bad thing. Fast-paced storytelling does not mean an incoherent narrative, and Puss in Boots: The Last Wish did a nice job in picking up any loose ends before the resolution. If anything, I'd prefer its quick pace of narration over a Hollywood action-adventure-scifi-romcom that has a thousand character arcs and spans over three hours.

All in all, take those morals or not, you're still going to enjoy the occasional jokes, top-tiered graphics design, interlinked story arcs, and finally that part of your childhood, revisited.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is a fun adventure in the "Shrek" universe! I gotta admit I have not seen the original film, and don't cherish the "Shrek" films as much as many do… so I went into this with mild expectations. And honestly, I had a good time; it was cute! Do I think it was as good as many other reviewers have suggested? No. But it was enjoyable, lighthearted fun that is perfect for families with kids! The voice cast was awesome, especially John Mulaney and Florence Pugh as the villains, Jack Horner and Goldilocks respectively. And of course Antonio Banderas as Puss in Boots is iconic as ever!

The animation here was gorgeous too, honestly it was one of my favourite parts. I love that major studio animated movies are finally starting to take more risks with their animation style, moving away from the typical 3D CGI realism. You gotta respect "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" for starting this trend and showing that different styles can work! I loved that this had a more watercolor, storybook illustration look to it, it really worked for the story and was employed in such creative ways! I would love to see the "Shrek" movies take this on, but alas they seem to have established their own look. This movie just looked so cool, so distinct in its own style, it really felt like I was watching a story in a fairy tale world.

Now, of course I have to admit I didn't love this movie. Something about it felt off to me, I couldn't seem to see where the acclaim was coming from. Sure, it was fun, it was cute, and I enjoyed myself while watching, but I never felt like I truly connected with the film. The opening scene felt a little jumbled to me, rapidly going from a musical sequence, to comedy for kids, to an action scene and I wished it would've let me settle into the story a bit first. I get this is a movie primarily for kids, but with most animation they tend to make parts enjoyable for the parents and older audiences as well. I don't really feel that here — they tried with the themes and the deeper storyline — but it never actually worked in my eyes. Everything felt very kid-focused, which isn't a bad thing, it just meant I wasn't the core audience and so it makes sense why I wouldn't enjoy it as much. I have to say, the kids in my theatre seemed to be having a blast! I'm sure this is a great movie for families with children, it just wasn't as good as I was told it would be.

I think the movie tried to do a bit of what Pixar is known for, the whole "trying to be deep" thing. The movie involves Puss in Boots coming to terms with death, and it seemed to be somewhat shallow, it never truly dove into this aspect of the story. Instead, the storyline is very linear and somewhat dull where it is just about the characters traveling to their destination and the villains sometimes catching up and then combat ensuing. And the physical goal literally being the spiritual goal just makes the inevitable plot point of "maybe I don't need the thing I wanted all long and it's the friends I made along the way that count" seem all the more predictable. Even Puss' relationship with the side characters is unchallenging. Although he is deeply flawed, his companions never seem to care about that and forgive him all the time. The chemistry of the characters was just nowhere as endearing as in "Shrek". Still the adventure was quite fun, I just didn't think the themes clicked as it felt like they were trying to be deep in a way that is not as organic and surprising as a film like Pixar's "Up", "Finding Nemo" or even DreamWorks' "How to Train Your Dragon". 

Perhaps I am being too harsh, I feel like this review is sounding more negative than anything. I really did have fun with it, and overall would give it a thumbs up, it's an enjoyable way to spend an hour and a half. The animation was really cool, the voice cast was great, and man I loved the little nods to the "Shrek" movies even if I was never a huge fan of those. If nothing else, this movie did make me really hopeful for another "Shrek" film. I do enjoy this fairy tale world and the creative animation they used to tell the story!

After seeing the overwhelmingly positive response to this movie, and all the great critics reviews, all I can say is that I must have seen a completely different movie. This was not only not amazing, it was actually pretty bad. I'm not even mad that it was bad, because Dreamworks hasn't been making good movies for about a decade now (sadly), so I wouldn't have bothered to see the movie except for the great reviews. And it is exactly as dumb as I originally thought it would be. If you think Puss in Boots 2 is a really great movie, trust me the bar is so much higher. Go watch the Dreamworks back catalog pre-2011, or Pixar pre-2010. If you want to watch a great animated movie made more recently, check out Spiderman Into the Spiderverse or The LEGO Movie. Also, GDT's Pinoccio was actually pretty solid. I don't want to demean anyone's tastes, just know that if you love animation and loved this movie, there is so much more great things to see so don't set your bar here. As for Dreamworks, I gotta say I'm so sad to see where you've ended up. I really miss the quality of movies you used to make. Prince of Egypt, Sinbad, El Dorado, Spirit, Kung Fu Panda 1&2, How to Train Your Dragon, Megamind, and even Shrek (I guess) these movies will all be remember long after your mediocre cash grabs such as Puss in Boots 2 are long forgotten.

This is one of Dreamwork's best movies yet. It's so good from the animation to the pacing to the story itself, and the themes/messages woven throughout are not only hard-hitting but also genuine and raw. The wolf as the villain is wonderful and the side characters are all loveable, particularly Perrito and Goldi and the Three Bears. Kitty Softpaws and Puss's dynamic is hilarious yet beautiful, and their arc throughout the movie is incredible. I'm not even going to try to describe how amazed I was at Puss's development throughout the film, how he goes from an adventure-driven, self-obsessed and reckless swashbuckler to a more humble and introspective (but still swashbuckling!) cat, having learned from his experiences throughout all of his nine lives and through his encounters with death - literally. 
I loved this movie so, so much and I could probably talk about it all day, but I won't keep you. GO SEE IT!!

La saga de Shrek es  muy irregular  solo las 2 primeras películas son buenas y la primera del gato con botas no fue muy rescatable ni recordable , pero en esta ocasión está película parece ofrecer una esperanza de renacer , ya que con una animación espectacular y un guión bastante filosófico nos brinda una película bastante encantadora poniendose  como la segunda película animada del año solo por debajo de pinocho de Guillermo del toro.
  Esta película es un deleite en todos sentido , es graciosa y es emotiva en momentos brindado un regreso que Dreamworks necesitaba , perrito es un personaje hermoso  que enamora desde el primer momento que aparece y  hasta el último momento de la película lo amas ,
El gato sigue siendo tan carismático y menos pesado que en las últimas películas de la saga ya que recupera su  brillo al ser vulnerable y lo vuelve más cercano , el lobo como la representación de la muerte es otro punto genial de la película es brillante y espero se destaque en futuras películas .

En los puntos flojos es el doblaje argentino de rizitos de oro y los 3 osos qu desentona muchísimo en comparación con el doblaje mexicano , sin embargo los los personajes son geniales y el doblaje no los arruina .
por otro lado la gata no tiene  nada que aportar es un personaje poco relevante más que para el chiste de los ojos de gato , el villano es interesante si es amenazante pero me quedé con ganas de que lo desarrollen mas pero no es malo me agrado , el Pepe grillo fue divertido y genial con la voz deo maestro Francisco colmenaro y el giro de que fuera la conciencia del villano me gustó que se rindió al ver que el tipo era irredimible 
C: 8.4/10

I love the character of Puss in Boots! However, when he finally got his own solo movie, I couldn't help but find it underwhelming! It wasn't awful, I just didn't have the energy that I wanted. Turns out, The Last Wish is everything that I wanted from the first Puss in Boots!
The animation is quick yet detailed, a lot of the comedy is really dark and really funny, the action sequences are incredibly fast and creative, and the movie has a lot of great drama and heart.
The movie does have flaws though. Because everything feels so fast, the pacing can often times feel really rushed, and some of the comedy can come off as a little annoying.
But still, this movie was better than it had any right to be! This is almost everything that I wanted from a Puss in Boots movie and, although it's no game changer, it is satisfyingly fun!

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is fast and fun, with surprisingly deep themes. This is a movie that I think all ages can definitely enjoy together, but I can see kids completely eating up. I really like this new visual style DreamWorks has been doing lately and think it looks really cool. The story is solid but I think more than anything I liked the emotions the film genuinely is able to earn with its characters and messages. There is a good amount of humor and action that also keeps the movie's pace moving consistently. Overall, it is a sweet movie you can see with the whole family and one that features some really visually slick animation.

A truly heartwarming story that succeeds in creating its own story while still being part of the Shrek universe. The movie is actually really good at building up tension, it's characters have clear motivations and are easy to empathize with
And it's actually a surprising good movie to watch during Christmas! (I know Avatar is a great choice for Christmas in 2022 as well but still). Furthermore: beautiful animation style (comic-like) and a joy for all audience ages. It is also oddly therapeutic. Or should I say oddly therapy dog?

There are so many things to love about this movie. It's visually stunning , with some scenes departing from straight CGI to a sort of drawn animation & comic book shadowing and sensibility in a sort of Akira Toriyama effect. Great action scenes over visually rich backdrops and ambience. The humor was very well done and I found the jokes quite funny. The voice actors were perfect. And there were interesting nods to external cultural memes that were a lot of fun such as several obvious references to specific Sergio Leone western scenes and style flourishes. And after all, any 2022 film that has a Jiminy Cricket knockoff character with a Jimmy Stewart inspired voice has something going on worthwhile.

An overall charming movie that will stand the test of time and will set an industry standard for animation.

The music, story and animation come together to form this masterpiece. I'm not kidding.
Sure, it has some jokes aimed at kids (being a kids movie and all) but the movie quickly turns around to show you either the most beautiful and dynamic animation you've seen since Spiderverse, or the most bone chilling and thrilling fight scenes.

And the music is excellent, just like the first movie, making use of it's Spanish influence to bring you some great bops.

Best in the franchise since Shrek 2 by a wide margin, the comedy is the sharpest I've seen from DreamWorks in years and it proves beyond a shadow of a doubt that they still have as much fresh edge as they did from day 1. The animation is obviously inspired by Spiderverse, and it gives the film a sense of kinetic energy and striking spectacle that I was really hoping to see more of from the studio after the brilliant presentation of Bad Guys. The emotional beats accomplish their goals pretty well, especially when it comes to a certain family, but a little more depth to the main antagonist would have been appreciated to make the final confrontation feel a touch more meaningful. Overall, a fantastic movie that squashes all worries I had for the next steps that DreamWorks are shaping up to take in the Shrek franchise

What an adventure! New fun characters, wonderful animation, and a unique story make this film worthy of the titular legend feline. 

I really appreciate the characters, especially two outstanding villain characters (Arguably, some of the best to come from the studio ever), no spoilers. There was no character I didn't like, which is a rarity. It was also very funny at times, I even had to hold back laughter in the theater. 

The art style, especially the backgrounds, reminds me of the original way the settings were done by hand painting on animated films such as Disney's Bambi (1942). This film brings back such artistic styles which founded animation; Styles that have been replaced and critically forgotten over the last few decades. It is a similar animation style to that in Spiderman: Into The Spiderverse (2018), yet it was more painting-like and less comic book-like. It truly did make me feel as if I was inside a fairytale world.

Addressing some fellow audience critiques, one villain in particular definitely sent chills down my spine when he appeared, enough so that any child might want to advert eyes for a second or two. This is a true villain character. It is important to recognize that even if a villain may be scary, that is the point. As far as that kind of villain being in a movie with children in mind, if you think about it over the years films have lacked such despicable characters, especially looking back at some earlier animation films from big studios including Disney. Therefore, this really shouldn't be a factor in limiting any child to see this film under your advisement (It is PG for this reason). 

After seeing this unexpectedly great film, I wouldn't be opposed to a sequel or other future films, especially with the same style as in this film. Perhaps even, this is further motivation to prepare for the 5th installment in a particular franchise in the same universe.

Review: Part 2 - Puss in Boots: The Last Wish was a much better movie than what I thought it was going to be.
